crashed into a crowd of people who had been <!--before changing this, DISCUSS on the talk page-->peacefully protesting the [[Unite the Right rally]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]]. The 20-year-old driver of the car, James Alex Fields Jr., had previously espoused [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazi]] and [[white supremacy|white supremacist]] beliefs.<ref name="cincinnati" /><ref name="usatodayP" /> Fields was charged with [[hit and run]], [[first-degree murder]] of 32-year-old Heather Heyer, multiple counts of federal hate crimes for injuring 28 others, and other crimes.
A memorial service and vigils were organized. The [[List of mayors of Charlottesville, Virginia|mayor of Charlottesville]], the [[Virginia Secretary of Public Safety]], the [[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]] and the [[Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI director]] called the attack [[domestic terrorism]].
== Background == [[File:Charlottesville 'Unite the Right' Rally (35780274914) crop.jpg|thumb|left|Rally participants are preparing to enter [[Emancipation Park (Charlottesville, Virginia)|Emancipation Park]] in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]] on August 12, 2017. They carry [[Confederate battle flag]]s, [[Gadsden flag]]s, and a [[Nazi flag]].]]{{OSM Location map | coord = {{Coord|38|01|48.80|N|78|28|45.15|W}} | zoom = 17 | float = right | caption = | title = | width = 400 | height = 350 | mark-coord = {{Coord|38|01|46.17|N|78|28|46.29|W}} | label = The attack | label-pos = right | scalemark = 30 | mark-coord2 = {{coord|38|1|54|N|78|28|50|W}} | label2 = Lee statue | label-pos2 = bottom | label-offset-x2 = -11 }} The [[Unite the Right rally]] was a [[white supremacy|white supremacist]] rally that occurred in [[Charlottesville, Virginia]] from August 11 to 12, 2017.<ref name="nationalview">{{cite news|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/13/us/far-right-groups-blaze-into-national-view-in-charlottesville.html|date=August 13, 2017|title=Far-Right Groups Surge Into National View In Charlottesville|first1=Richard|last1=Fausset|first2=Alan|last2=Feuer|dead-url=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170816015808/https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/13/us/far-right-groups-blaze-into-national-view-in-charlottesville.html|archivedate=August 16, 2017|df=mdy-all|accessdate=May 24, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=One killed in US far-right rally violence|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-40912509|publisher=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=May 24, 2018|date=August 13, 2017}}</ref> [[Jason Kessler]], the organizer of the rally, had been protesting for months [[Robert Edward Lee (sculpture)#Protests against its removal|the proposed removal of a statue]] of [[Robert E. Lee]] in [[Emancipation Park (Charlottesville, Virginia)|Emancipation Park]] in Charlottesville.<ref name="nationalview"/>
Individuals and groups of different beliefs and tactics demonstrated against the rally. Many counter-protesters were ready to turn out despite the threat of violence. Protesters and some militant counterprotesters were attacking each other.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stockman|first1=Farah|title=Who Were the Counterprotesters in Charlottesville?|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/14/us/who-were-the-counterprotesters-in-charlottesville.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=May 24, 2018|date=August 14, 2017}}</ref>
On August 12, 2017, a [[maroon]] [[minivan]] and a white [[Toyota Camry]] [[Sedan (automobile)|sedan]] behind it were driving down the Fourth Street Southeast crossing of the [[Downtown Mall]] toward Water Street and were stopped by a large group of counter-protesters who decided to walk up Fourth Street Southeast in the direction of Market Street.<ref name="dpDec"/><ref name="dec17wapo"/> A gray 2010 [[Dodge Challenger]] drove down Fourth Street Southeast mall crossing and idled for a short time behind the white Toyota at the Downtown Mall.<ref name="npr"/><ref name="dpDec"/><ref name="dec17wapo"/> It then backed up and traveled more than a block before rapidly accelerating.<ref name="dec17wapo"/> {{clear left}} == The attack == [[File:2017 Charlottesville, Virginia car attack seen from pole.jpg|thumb|left|Photograph of the attack taken by Jeremiah Knupp for ''[[The News Leader]]'']][[File:Dodge Challenger Coquitlam (cropped).JPG|thumb|right|A 2010 Dodge Challenger, similar to the vehicle involved. However, whilst this image retains stock rims, the car involved in the attack had black aftermarket rims, but the color remains the same]][[File:2017 Charlottesville vehicle-ramming attack.webm|thumb|left|Video footage of the attack taken by [[Brennan Gilmore]]]] At around 1:45 p.m. on August 12, 2017, the 2010 Dodge Challenger impacted a crowd of counter-protesters while driving at a high speed.<ref name="maggie" /><ref name="wapoHSSB" /><ref name="npr" /><ref name="dpDec" /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Shulleeta|first1=Brandon|title=At least one dead as white nationalists ignite Virginia clashes|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-virginia-protests-idUSKBN1AS05T|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=May 24, 2018|date=August 12, 2018}}</ref> It audibly rammed pedestrians and struck the white sedan.<ref name="npr" /> The impact reportedly "[shoved] tons of metal into the crowd" and sent people "flying through the air" and over another car near the intersection with Water Street East.<ref name="npr" /><ref name="splscvc" /> The struck vehicle also hit the maroon minivan ahead, "sending that vehicle into more pedestrians".<ref name="npr" /> A few seconds after the initial impact, Fields drove in reverse—hitting more people—with his car's front bumper "scraping the road".<ref name="npr" /><ref name="dpDec" /> Pedestrians who had avoided the attack chased Fields along Fourth Street.<ref name="npr" />
Fields backed up at a high speed for several blocks, and then turned left and sped off down Market Street.<ref name="dpDec" /><ref name="cincinnatiBSSC" /> A [[Virginia State Police]] [[Bell 407]] helicopter, that [[Unite the Right rally#Fatal helicopter crash|crashed about three hours later]], was following the car and relaying its route to ground units.<ref name="dpDec"/><ref name="dec17wapo">{{cite web|last1=Duggan|first1=Paul|title=Charge upgraded to first-degree murder for driver accused of ramming Charlottesville crowd|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/crime/driver-accused-of-plowing-into-charlottesville-crowd-killing-heather-heyer-due-in-court/2017/12/13/6cbb4ce8-e029-11e7-89e8-edec16379010_story.html|website=The Washington Post|accessdate=May 24, 2018|date=December 14, 2017}}</ref> A deputy stopped and arrested Fields on Monticello Avenue, about a mile from the attack.<ref name="dpDec" /><ref name="increases" /> The deputy waited for the police to arrive, and detective Steven Young came from the police department. According to Young, Fields kept apologizing and asked if anyone was injured. When Young told him that a person had died, Fields appeared shocked and started to cry.<ref name="dpDec"/><ref name="dec17wapo"/><ref>{{cite web |last1=Stockman |first1=Farah |title=The Charlottesville Murder Trial Is Beginning. Here’s What to Know. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/29/us/charlottesville-murder-trial-james-fields.html |website=The New York Times |accessdate=November 29, 2018 |language=en |date=November 29, 2018}}</ref> Young said that the Dodge had holes in the rear window—made by counter-protesters after the initial impact<ref name="increases" /><ref>{{cite web |last1=Hartung |first1=Kaylee |last2=Simon |first2=Darran |title=Suspect in Charlottesville car attack faces first-degree murder charge |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/12/14/us/charlottesville-james-alex-fields-court-appearance/index.html |publisher=CNN |accessdate=July 30, 2018 |date=December 15, 2017}}</ref>—and heavy front-end damage; Young said that the car was "splattered" with blood and flesh. A pair of blue sunglasses was stuck in the spoiler on the car's trunk.<ref name="dpDec"/>
Heather Heyer, a 32-year-old woman, was fatally injured in the attack, and died at the [[University of Virginia Medical Center]].<ref name="cincinnatiBSSC" /><ref name="hh" /> Initially, nineteen injuries were reported, as twenty patients were taken at the University of Virginia Medical Center.<ref name="dec17wapo" /><ref name="cincinnatiBSSC" /> In the evening, five people were in critical condition and fourteen others were being treated for lesser injuries.<ref name="splscvc" /> Nine people had been discharged and ten remained hospitalized in good condition the next day.<ref name="vigilUSAT">{{cite web |last1=Bacon |first1=John |last2=King |first2=Robert |last3=Toy |first3=Sarah |title=Vigil for Charlottesville victim canceled, but mourners meet at crash site |url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2017/08/13/charlottesville-mayor-rips-unite-right-leader-blames-city-violence/562914001/ |website=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=July 11, 2018 |language=en |date=August 14, 2017}}</ref><ref name="SLwapo13" /> Testimony at the preliminary hearing in December 2017 revealed that a total of 35 people were injured.<ref name="dec17wapo"/>
The organizer of the Unite the Right rally, Jason Kessler, held a news conference near the Charlottesville City Hall the day after the car attack. A crowd of around a hundred counter-protesters shouted him down, screaming "murderer". A few protesters then broke through the line of reporters and headed toward Kessler. The police brought Kessler into the City Hall after a counter-protester made an [[the finger|obscene gesture]] and another counter-protester lunged at him. Twenty minutes later, the police formed a line and Kessler ran out of a door at the side of the building and lunged into the back of a marked police SUV. As the SUV sped away, a single counter-protester chased it, yelling, "Shame! Shame! Shame!"<ref name="splscvc"/> In February 2018, three were found guilty of assaulting Kessler at the news conference and a case against a person charged with spitting on Kessler was continued until February 2019 at the request of the prosecution.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Berg |first1=Lauren |title=Three found guilty of assaulting Kessler at Aug. 13 press conference |url=http://www.dailyprogress.com/news/three-found-guilty-of-assaulting-kessler-at-aug-press-conference/article_040c36a6-0880-11e8-9d26-af6005eca6ba.html |website=The Daily Progress |accessdate=August 1, 2018 |language=en |date=February 2, 2018}}</ref> {{clear left}} == Suspect == '''James Alex Fields Jr.''' (born April 26, 1997<ref name="cincinnatiBSSC"/>) was the driver of the car. Fields grew up with his mother Samantha Bloom, a [[Paraplegia|paraplegic]], in [[Florence, Kentucky]].<ref name="npr"/><ref name="splscvc"/><ref name="wapoBail">{{cite web|last1=Hernández|first1=Arelis R.|last2=Gillum|first2=Jack|last3=Miller|first3=Michael E.|last4=Hendrix|first4=Steve|title='Very threatening': Mother of Charlottesville suspect James A. Fields called 911 twice|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/judge-denies-bail-for-man-accused-of-ramming-car-into-charlottesville-protesters/2017/08/14/2177a028-80fd-11e7-ab27-1a21a8e006ab_story.html|website=The Washington Post|accessdate=May 26, 2018|date=August 14, 2017}}</ref> After living in southwest Florence for ten years, they moved to [[Monclova Township, Lucas County, Ohio]] for her job in late 2016.<ref name="npr"/><ref name="cincinnatiPast"/><ref name="wapoBail"/><ref name="cincinnati13"/><ref name="cincinnatiM">{{cite web|last1=Sparling|first1=Hannah|last2=Balmert|first2=Jessie|last3=Stinchcomb|first3=Jon|title=Community: Accused Charlottesville driver James Alex Fields Jr. doesn't represent us|url=https://eu.cincinnati.com/story/news/2017/08/13/maumee-neighbors-shaken-charlottesville-suspect-james-alex-fields-living-nearby/563055001/|website=The Cincinnati Enquirer|accessdate=May 27, 2018|language=en|date=August 14, 2017}}</ref> Fields' mother told the ''[[The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)|Toledo Blade]]'' that he had "recently moved out on his own".<ref name="cincinnatiM"/>
Until his arrest in Charlottesville, Fields worked for about two years as a security guard in Ohio; he earned {{USD|10.50}} per hour and his income was $650 every two weeks.<ref name="hateWAPO"/><ref name="wapoBail"/> According to acquaintances, Fields "filled his time" playing video games and working at a local grocery store.<ref name="blinder"/>
According to Fields' high school history teacher, Derek Weimer, Fields was prescribed an [[antipsychotic]] as [[Anger_management#Medication|anger management medication]] after he had been diagnosed with [[schizophrenia]].<ref name="wapoBail" /><ref name="usatodayP">{{cite web|last1=Pilcher|first1=James|title=Charlottesville suspect's beliefs were 'along the party lines of the neo-Nazi movement,' ex-teacher says|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/08/13/charlottesville-suspects-views-neo-nazi-ex-teacher/563199001/|website=[[USA Today]]|accessdate=May 26, 2018|language=en|date=August 14, 2017}}</ref> Fields told a judge that he was receiving treatment for [[bipolar disorder]], anxiety, depression and [[attention deficit hyperactivity disorder]] (ADHD).<ref name="Associated Press thru NBC" />
Fields' father was killed in a car crash on December 5, 1996, five months before he was born.<ref name="blinder"/><ref name="cincinnatiPast" /> Bloom's parents died in a murder-suicide when she was 16 on August 21, 1984 when Bloom's father, 42-year-old self-employed contractor Marvin killed his 37-year-old ex-wife Judy, and himself.<ref name="cincinnatiPast"/><ref name="splscvc"/>
=== Biography === Fields threatened his mother with violence on multiple occasions. In November 2010, in a bathroom she locked, afraid of her son, Fields' mother reported to the police that he had threatened to beat her, took her phone, smacked her head, and put his hands over her mouth, after she told him to stop playing video games.<ref name="cincinnatiPast">{{cite web|last1=Strickley|first1=Bob|last2=Brookbank|first2=Sarah|last3=Graves|first3=Chris|last4=Mayhew|first4=Chris|title=911 calls, records reveal tumultuous past for accused Charlottesville driver, family|url=https://eu.cincinnati.com/story/news/local/northern-ky/2017/08/14/mom-previously-accused-charlottesville-driver-james-alex-fields-jr-beating-her/566078001/|website=The Cincinnati Enquirer|accessdate=May 27, 2018|language=en|date=August 15, 2017}}</ref><ref name="wapoBail"/> In February 2011, Fields' mother reported to the police at 5:20 a.m. that he had not come home; she said that he was wearing a T-shirt and shorts. Two hours later, she reported to the police that Fields "was home and acting [[Lethargy|lethargic]]"; he threatened to run away "if police came to the condo".<ref name="cincinnatiPast"/> In October 2011, Fields threatened her with a {{convert|12|inch|cm|adj=on}} knife; she called the police the next day to say that her son had been "very threatening" toward her and that she was scared and did not feel in control of the situation because she was in a wheelchair. In November 2011, Fields spat in his mother's face and threatened her, and a woman requested that the police help Fields' mother get him to a hospital for assessment; the log for the call reads, "Mom is scared he is going to become violent here."<ref name="cincinnatiPast"/><ref name="wapoBail"/> Fields was subsequently arrested and held in juvenile detention.<ref name="wapoBail"/>
When he was a [[Twelfth grade|senior]] in high school, Fields applied to join the Army, and Weimer, who was a former [[Ohio National Guard]] officer, helped him because Weimer believed that the military "would expose Fields to people of different races and backgrounds and help him dispel his white supremacist views". Fields was turned down which Weimer called a "big blow".<ref name="usatodayP"/> Fields entered the Army on August 18, 2015 and was released from active duty "due to a failure to meet training standards" on December 11, the same year.<ref name="usatodayP"/><ref name="cincinnati13"/> Army spokeswoman [[Lieutenant colonel|Lt. Col.]] Jennifer Johnson said that Fields "was never awarded a military occupational skill nor was he assigned to a unit outside of basic training".<ref name="blinder"/> Weimer lost contact with Fields after he had graduated, and was "surprised" when he heard that Fields had enlisted in the Army.<ref name="usatodayP"/>
Fields graduated [[Randall K. Cooper High School]] in 2015.<ref name="cincinnatiPast"/>
Fields purchased his first car, the 2010 Dodge Challenger, used in the attack, from a [[Cincinnati metropolitan area]] car dealership in Florence in June 2015.<ref name="blinder"/><ref name="cincinnatiBSSC" /><ref name="cincinnati13" /> The car was last registered in Ohio, and Fields updated its title in [[Maumee, Ohio]] in July 2015. ''The Cincinnati Enquirer'' reported that, according to local court records, he was cited for expired or unlawful license plates by the Maumee police in May 2017.<ref name="cincinnatiBSSC"/>
=== Ideology === An ex-schoolmate of Fields said that Fields would draw swastikas and talk about "loving Hitler" as early as [[middle school]].<ref name="cincinnatiPast" /> Fields' high school history teacher said that Fields was "deeply into Adolf Hitler and white supremacy".<ref name="npr" /><ref name="cincinnati">{{cite web|last1=Pilcher|first1=James|title=Charlottesville suspect's beliefs were 'along the party lines of the neo-Nazi movement,' ex-teacher says|url=https://eu.cincinnati.com/story/news/local/northern-ky/2017/08/13/charlottesville-suspects-beliefs-were-along-party-lines-neo-nazi-movement-ex-teacher-says/563139001/|website=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]|accessdate=May 26, 2018|language=en|date=August 14, 2017}}</ref> The teacher, Derek Weimer, reportedly taught Fields in three classes at Randall K. Cooper High School and "had regular interaction with him after classes and during free time".<ref name="npr" /><ref name="cincinnati" /> He told ''[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]'', "I'm sure if you would ask James he would say I was his favorite or one of his favorite teachers." Weimer said that Fields was "a very bright kid but very misguided and disillusioned".<ref name="cincinnati" /> Weimer said, "Once you talked to James for a while, you would start to see that sympathy towards Nazism, that idolization of Hitler, that belief in white supremacy. It would start to creep out."<ref name="usatb">{{cite web|last1=Toy|first1=Sarah|last2=Bacon|first2=John|title=No bail for Charlottesville car attack suspect James Fields|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2017/08/14/james-alex-fields-jr-charlottesville-car-attack-suspect-faces-hearing-today/564002001/|website=USA Today|accessdate=May 27, 2018|language=en|date=August 14, 2017}}</ref> Weimer said that he had done his best to steer Fields away from those interests and had thought that he had succeeded in doing so.<ref name="npr" /> He said that he felt like he failed as a teacher because of the attack, but that "this is definitely a teachable moment and something we need to be vigilant about, because this stuff is tearing up our country".<ref name="splscvc">{{cite web |last1=Shapiro |first1=T. Rees |last2=Crites |first2=Alice |last3=Vozzella |first3=Laura |last4=Cox |first4=John Woodrow |title=Alleged driver of car that plowed into Charlottesville crowd was a Nazi sympathizer, former teacher says |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/one-dead-as-car-strikes-crowds-amid-protests-of-white-nationalist-gathering-in-charlottesville-two-police-die-in-helicopter-crash/2017/08/13/3590b3ce-8021-11e7-902a-2a9f2d808496_story.html |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=July 27, 2018 |language=en |date=August 13, 2017}}</ref><ref name="npr" /><ref name="cincinnati" /> Weimer said that another teacher had filed a report during Fields' freshman year because he had written something that was "very much along the party lines of the neo-Nazi movement".<ref name="cincinnati" /><ref name="usatodayP" /> He said that it "would have been standard procedure" to notify Fields' mother and that the school administrators "were very good about keeping parents in the loop".<ref name="cincinnati" />
According to Weimer, Fields "left school for a while" and became quieter about politics when he came back, until his senior year, when the candidates for the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]] were declared. Weimer said that Fields supported [[Donald Trump]] because of what he perceived were [[Racial views of Donald Trump|Trump's racial views]]. According to Weimer, Fields supported [[Mexico–United States barrier#Trump administration|Trump's Mexico border proposal]]. Weimer said that Fields "admired" the [[Confederate States of America]] for [[Military of the Confederate States of America|their military]], though they "never spoke about slavery".<ref name="usatodayP"/> Weimer said that "the constant presence of the Confederate flag was an ongoing issue" and that an African-American cheerleader was "very uncomfortable having to ride in a parade being carried by a pickup truck with a large Confederate flag sticker".<ref name="cincinnati"/> Fields reportedly made students feel "unnerved" and "unsafe", and one woman told ''[[The New York Times]]'', "On many occasions there were times he would scream obscenities, whether it be about Hitler or racial slurs."<ref name="blinder"/> Fields' roommate on a class trip to Europe in 2015 told the [[Associated Press]] that Fields went on the trip only to visit Germany, and referred to it as the [[Fatherland]]. He couldn't handle being in a room with Fields after Fields spoke about French people "being lower than us and inferior to us".<ref name="apRoommate">{{cite web |last1=Kang |first1=Dake |last2=Rankin |first2=Sarah |title=Charlottesville driver previously accused of beating mother |url=https://www.apnews.com/ffec757d4c084bcda2c9ee4224e91c36/Mom-previously-accused-Charlottesville-driver-of-beating-her |website=AP News |accessdate=August 9, 2018 |date=August 16, 2017}}</ref> Fields voted in the March 15, 2016 [[Ohio Republican primary, 2016|Ohio Republican primary]].<ref name="blinder" />
{{quote |text=A lot of boys get interested in the Germans and Nazis because they're interested in World War II. But James took it to another level. He researched everything and had an intellectual argument for all his points, which is something you just don't see that often. |author=Derek Weimer |source=''[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]''<ref name="cincinnati" /> }}
Fields' mother said that he had a pet cat, and that she was taking care of it during the rally. She did not know that her son was attending a [[white supremacy|white supremacist]] rally; instead, she thought that he was attending a [[Donald Trump]]-related rally.<ref name="npr"/> She told him "to be careful, and if they're going to rally to make sure he's doing it peacefully".<ref name="cincinnatiBSSC">{{cite web|last1=Balmert|first1=Jessie|last2=Strickley|first2=Bob|last3=Stanglin|first3=Doug|last4=Cavallaro|first4=Gabe|title=Ohio man charged in Charlottesville vehicle attack grew up in NKY|url=https://eu.cincinnati.com/story/news/2017/08/12/car-hit-charlottesville-crowd-purchased-florence-registered-ohio-online-records-show/562283001/|website=The Cincinnati Enquirer|accessdate=May 27, 2018|language=en|date=August 15, 2017}}</ref> She said that she "would be surprised if her son's views were so far right that he would attend a white supremacist rally" and that he had an African-American friend.<ref name="npr" /><ref name="cincinnati" /> She told the ''Toledo Blade'' that she had not spoken with her son about his political views.<ref name="npr" /> Fields' Facebook page included [[Internet meme|memes]] and symbols associated with the far-right.<ref name="blinder" /> At the Unite the Right rally, the morning of the attack, Fields was seen wielding a [[Vanguard America]] shield. Vanguard America, a [[neo-Nazism|neo-Nazi]] organization, stated that it was not associated with Fields.<ref name="npr" /><ref name="increases" /> There is no evidence that Fields was affiliated with any of the groups assembled that day.<ref name="increases" />
=== Investigation and prosecution === Fields was initially charged with one count of [[second-degree murder]], three counts of [[malicious wounding]], and one count of [[hit and run]].<ref name="npr" /> On August 12, the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] announced a joint civil rights investigation into the incident conducted by the Justice Department's [[United States Department of Justice Civil Rights Division|Civil Rights Division]], the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] and the U.S. Attorney for the [[United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia|Western District of Virginia]].<ref name="npr" /><ref name="nytSR12">{{cite web |last1=Stolberg |first1=Sheryl Gay |last2=Rosenthal |first2=Brian M. |title=Man Charged After White Nationalist Rally in Charlottesville Ends in Deadly Violence |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/12/us/charlottesville-protest-white-nationalist.html |website=The New York Times |accessdate=July 9, 2018 |language=en |date=August 12, 2017}}</ref> [[NPR]]'s [[Carrie Johnson (journalist)|Carrie Johnson]] reported that investigators wanted to know whether Fields had crossed state lines with the intent to commit violence.<ref name="npr" /> A Department of Justice official said that federal hate crime charges could be applied to the case and that they would "investigate whether others may have been involved in planning the attack".<ref name="vigilUSAT" /> [[Lisa Monaco]], [[United States Homeland Security Advisor|Homeland Security Advisor]] to [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]], raised the question of whether the attack would be investigated as [[Domestic terrorism in the United States|domestic terrorism]].<ref name="domternyt13">{{cite web|last1=Savage|first1=Charlie|title=A Hate Crime? How the Charlottesville Car Attack May Become a Federal Case|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/13/us/politics/charlottesville-sessions-justice-department.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=May 24, 2018|date=August 13, 2017}}</ref> [[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[Jeff Sessions]] said on ''[[Good Morning America]]'' on August 14 that the attack met the definition of domestic terrorism.<ref name="wapoBail"/><ref name="domternyt13"/> Attorney General Jeff Sessions said that civil rights division FBI agents and FBI terrorism investigators were working on the case.<ref name="cincinnatiPast"/> FBI Director [[Christopher A. Wray]] said that the attack met the definition of domestic terrorism.<ref name="usatb"/> Fields was scheduled to appear in court on August 14.<ref name="npr"/> He appeared via video from jail and was denied bail.<ref name="cincinnatiPast"/> Fields said that he could not afford a lawyer; a private attorney was appointed by the judge, as a public defender could not be appointed due to a conflict of interest.<ref name="usatb"/><ref name="wapoBail"/> The next hearing for Fields was set for August 25.<ref name="cincinnatiPast" />
{{quote |text=You can be sure we will charge and advance the investigation towards the most serious charges that can be brought because this is unequivocally an unacceptable, evil attack. |author=[[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[Jeff Sessions]] |source=''[[Good Morning America]]'' (2017)<ref name="cincinnatiPast" /> }}
A week later, Fields was charged with two additional counts of malicious wounding, and three counts of [[Aggravation (law)|aggravated]] malicious wounding.<ref name="dpCharges">{{cite web|title=Fields faces 5 additional felony charges related to Aug. 12 fatal crash|url=http://www.dailyprogress.com/news/local/fields-faces-additional-felony-charges-related-to-aug-fatal-crash/article_7608f516-845d-11e7-986e-b73741c8b869.html|website=[[The Daily Progress]]|accessdate=May 24, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170819003212/http://www.dailyprogress.com/news/local/fields-faces-additional-felony-charges-related-to-aug-fatal-crash/article_7608f516-845d-11e7-986e-b73741c8b869.html|archivedate=August 19, 2017|language=en|date=August 18, 2017}}</ref> Charlottesville Police [[Lieutenant]] Steve Upman said in a release, "The victims related to these charges suffered serious injuries and in some cases permanent physical disabilities." The investigation remained under the Charlottesville police, the FBI and the DOJ.<ref name="dpCharges" />
At the preliminary hearing in December 2017, State District Court Judge Robert H. Downer Jr. certified all ten charges to a grand jury. The certified charges were one count of [[first-degree murder]], three counts of malicious wounding, three counts of aggravated malicious wounding, two counts of felonious assault and one count of hit and run. Video footage of the surveying helicopter and surveillance video footage from a restaurant near the mall crossing were shown.<ref name="dpDec" /> Surveillance video footage from the restaurant reportedly showed the Dodge Challenger zooming past "a string of vehicles" heading south on Fourth Street Southeast.<ref name="increases"/>
On January 3, 2018, Fields waived his right to a [[speedy trial]], and his trial was scheduled to begin on November 26, 2018, and last three weeks.<ref name="hateWAPO"/><ref>{{cite web |title=Fields set for three-week trial in November |url=https://www.dailyprogress.com/news/local/fields-set-for-three-week-trial-in-november/article_d497a604-f0be-11e7-bc83-f7eff49a1576.html |website=The Daily Progress |accessdate=August 1, 2018 |language=en |date=January 3, 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Indictment of James Alex Fields Jr.pdf|thumb|right|The federal indictment]] On June 27, 2018, as reported by the DOJ's Office of Public Affairs, a [[United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia|W.D. Va.]] federal grand jury charged Fields under two hate crime statutes with multiple federal [[hate crime]]s:<ref name="hateDOJ">{{cite web |title=Ohio Man Charged with Federal Hate Crimes Related to August 2017 Rally in Charlottesville |url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/ohio-man-charged-federal-hate-crimes-related-august-2017-rally-charlottesville |publisher=[[United States Department of Justice]] Office of Public Affairs PR |accessdate=August 1, 2018 |language=en |date=June 27, 2018}}</ref><ref name="hateWAPO">{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/man-accused-of-driving-into-crowd-at-unite-the-right-rally-charged-with-federal-hate-crimes/2018/06/27/09cdce3a-7a20-11e8-80be-6d32e182a3bc_story.html |title=Man accused of driving into crowd at 'Unite the Right' rally charged with federal hate crimes |last=Heim |first=Joe |date=June 27, 2018 |work=The Washington Post |access-date=June 27, 2018 |last2=Barrett |first2=Devlin |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="hateNYT">{{cite web |last1=Benner |first1=Katie |last2=Spencer |first2=Hawes |title=Charlottesville Car Attack Suspect Indicted on Federal Hate Crime Charges |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/27/us/politics/charlottesville-death-hate-crime-charges.html |website=The New York Times |accessdate=August 1, 2018 |language=en |date=June 27, 2018}}</ref>
*one count of a hate crime act resulting in the death of Heather Heyer (18 U.S.C. § 249); *28 counts of hate crime acts causing bodily injury and involving an attempt to kill (18 U.S.C. § 249); and *one count of racially motivated violent interference with a federally protected activity [[Hate crime laws in the United States#Civil Rights Act of 1968|(18 U.S.C. § 245(b)(2))]], resulting in the death of Heather Heyer, for driving his car into a crowd of protestors on a downtown street in Charlottesville, Virginia.<ref name="hateDOJ" />
Attorney General Jeff Sessions said of the indictment, "Last summer's violence in Charlottesville cut short a promising young life and shocked the nation. Today's indictment should send a clear message to every would-be criminal in America that we aggressively prosecute violent crimes of hate that threaten the core principles of our nation." W.D. Va. Attorney [[Thomas T. Cullen]] called the indictment "the culmination of a 10-month investigation that involved searching the social media accounts where Mr. Fields showed an interest in harming minorities". [[Adam S. Lee]], the [[Special Agent in Charge|special agent in charge]] of the FBI's [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] Division, said, "Heyer did not go to the event looking for a fight. She was looking to lend her voice to her cause. Peaceful protest without intimidation, without the threat of violence is every American's birthright."<ref name="hateWAPO"/>
On July 5, 2018, Fields [[plea]]ded not guilty to all 30 counts of federal hate crime charges.<ref name="notguilty">{{cite web |last1=Strickley |first1=Bob |title=NKY native James Alex Fields pleads not guilty in Charlottesville attack |url=https://eu.cincinnati.com/story/news/crime/crime-and-courts/2018/07/05/james-alex-fields-alleged-driver-pleads-not-guilty-charlottesville-attack/761153002/ |website=The Cincinnati Enquirer |accessdate=July 27, 2018 |language=en |date=July 6, 2018}}</ref>
The trial was set to begin on November 26, 2018.<ref name="Associated Press thru NBC">{{cite news |title=James Alex Fields' trial in deadly Charlottesville white nationalist rally set to begin |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/james-alex-fields-trial-deadly-charlottesville-white-nationalist-rally-set-n939991 |accessdate=November 27, 2018 |agency=Associated Press |date=November 26, 2018}}</ref> {{clear right}}<!--please add new paragraphs to the above section above this line -->
== Heather Heyer == {{Infobox person | name = Heather Heyer | image = Heather Heyer.jpg | image_upright = 0.7 | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{birth date|1985|5|29}}<ref name="theparamount">{{cite web|url=http://www.theparamount.net/heather/|title=Heather Heyer Memorial|publisher=[[Paramount Theater (Charlottesville, Virginia)|Paramount Theater]]}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Charlottesville, Virginia]]<ref name="theparamount" /> | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|8|12|1985|5|29}} | death_place = Charlottesville, Virginia | death_cause = [[Blunt trauma|Blunt-force]] [[Chest injury|trauma to the chest]]<ref name="newsweek">{{cite web|last1=Porter|first1=Tom|title=Anti-racism activist Heather Heyer's cause of death has been revealed in a medical report|url=http://www.newsweek.com/charlottesville-heather-heyers-cause-death-revealed-medical-report-686471|website=[[Newsweek]]|accessdate=May 24, 2018|language=en|date=October 17, 2017}}</ref> | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = [[Bartender]], [[waitress]], [[paralegal]]<ref name="hh" /> }}
'''Heather Danielle Heyer'''<ref name="SLwapo13" /> (May 29, 1985 – August 12, 2017) was the only person killed in the attack.
Heyer grew up in [[Ruckersville, Virginia]], and graduated from [[William Monroe High School]] in [[Stanardsville, Virginia]].<ref name="theparamount" /> She worked as a bartender and waitress.<ref name="hh" /> She was approached by Alfred A. Wilson, the manager of the bankruptcy division at the Miller Law Group in Charlottesville.<ref name="hh" /> Heyer did not have a background in law; Wilson hired her at the recommendation of a friend and said that she "had an eye for detail" and was "a people person".<ref name="hh" /> He reportedly told her, "If you can get people to open up to you, that's what I need. I'll teach you everything about the law you need to know."<ref name="hh" /> She continued her job as a waitress while working at the law firm.<ref name="hh" /> Wilson said that Heyer did not take any vacations during her first two years at Miller Law Group.<ref name="hh" /> Heyer left her boyfriend after he made a racist comment about Wilson.<ref name="hh">{{cite web|last1=Caron|first1=Christina|title=Heather Heyer, Charlottesville Victim, Is Recalled as 'a Strong Woman'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/13/us/heather-heyer-charlottesville-victim.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=May 24, 2018|date=August 13, 2017}}</ref><ref name="wapoMemorial">{{cite web |last1=Silverman |first1=Ellie |last2=Hernández |first2=Arelis R. |last3=Hendrix |first3=Steve |title='They tried to kill my child to shut her up,' Heather Heyer's mother mourns at funeral for woman killed during Nazi protest in Charlottesville |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/heather-heyers-grieving-mother-readies-herself-for-huge-public-farewell-to-my-child/2017/08/15/c5270e5e-81fa-11e7-ab27-1a21a8e006ab_story.html |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=July 9, 2018 |language=en |date=August 16, 2017}}</ref>
Heyer lived alone.<ref name="hh"/><ref name="SLwapo13"/> Her friends described her "as a passionate advocate for the disenfranchised who was often moved to tears by the world's injustices", and said that she "spoke out against inequality and urged co-workers to be active in their community".<ref name="hh"/> According to Heyer's mother Susan Bro, Heyer would ask people of opposing views why they had come to their beliefs. Bro said that she and Heyer advocated for [[Black Lives Matter]], which Bro said fights for equal treatment.<ref name="SLwapo13">{{cite web |last1=Silverman |first1=Ellie |last2=Laris |first2=Michael |title=Charlottesville victim: 'She was there standing up for what was right' |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/charlottesville-victim-she-was-there-standing-up-for-what-was-right/2017/08/13/00d6b034-8035-11e7-b359-15a3617c767b_story.html |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=16 July 2018 |language=en |date=August 13, 2017}}</ref>
{{quote |text=If you're not outraged, you're not paying attention. |author=Heather Heyer |source=her last post published on [[Facebook]]<ref name="increases">{{cite web|last1=Spencer|first1=Hawes|last2=Pérez-Peña|first2=Richard|authorlink2=Richard Pérez-Peña|title=Murder Charge Increases in Charlottesville Protest Death|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/12/14/us/charlottesville-fields-white-supremists.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=May 24, 2018|date=December 14, 2017}}</ref> }}
{{quote |text=I've never had a close friend like this be murdered. We thought, "What would Heather do?" Heather would go harder. So that's what we're going to do. We're going to preach love. We're going to preach equality, and Heather's death won't be in vain.<ref name="hh" /> |author=Marissa Blair }}
Heyer and a longtime friend of hers had agreed not to protest the Unite the Right rally, because they thought it would be too dangerous, but the night before the protests, Heyer felt compelled to go.<ref name="SLwapo13" />
== Reactions == === Memorial service === A memorial service was held at the [[Paramount Theater (Charlottesville, Virginia)|Paramount Theater]], two blocks from the attack location, on August 16. More than a thousand people attended the service, many of them wearing sashes and ribbons. Present were [[Governor of Virginia|Governor]] [[Terry McAuliffe]] (D-VA), junior Senator [[Tim Kaine]] (D-VA), gubernatorial candidate [[Lieutenant Governor of Virginia|Lt. Gov.]] [[Ralph Northam]] (D-VA) and gubernatorial candidate and former [[Counselor to the President]] [[Ed Gillespie]] (R-VA).<ref name="wapoMemorial"/>
Heyer's mother Susan Bro delivered a speech calling for people to fight "as Heather would do".<ref name="wapoMemorial" /> A standing ovation lasted nearly a minute and a half after Bro said, "They tried to kill my child to shut her up, but guess what, you just magnified her."<ref name="wapoMemorial" /><ref name="brotrumpnyt" /> Bro said that she had received hundreds of messages from people inspired by Heyer asking for advice. A woman played "[[Amazing Grace]]" and "[[America the Beautiful]]" on a saxophone. Heyer's father Mark Heyer said that Heather had been "defiant, strong-willed and compassionate" and that she "always argued for what she thought was right".<ref name="wapoMemorial" />
Several people with purple shields, pink bats and pink helmets with a heart drawn on each were observing outside the theater to stop any "fascist groups" that might disrupt the event. No problems were reported outside the theater. As the service ended, Bro asked someone in the audience to stop criticizing President Trump.<ref name="wapoMemorial"/>
[[File:Tim Kaine inspects a makeshift memorial to Heather Heyer.jpg|thumb|right|Senator [[Tim Kaine]] of Virginia inspects a makeshift memorial to Heather Heyer at the site of her death.]] Politicians were confronted outside the memorial service. After being asked about it, McAuliffe told a man that Virginia law leaves the [[Removal of Confederate monuments and memorials|removal of Confederate statues]] to local communities. Kaine was asked why the Charlottesville police "had failed to head off the weekend's violent clashes" and he "said [that] city officials had promised an independent review of the police response".<ref name="wapoMemorial"/>
=== Vigils === A vigil in remembrance of Heyer was planned for August 13 night, but was cancelled due to a "credible threat from white supremacists". People gathered and prayed at the site of the attack in spite of the cancellation.<ref name="vigilUSAT" />
Hundreds of people gathered at the [[University of Virginia]] and in other U.S. cities, including [[Philadelphia]] and [[Akron, Ohio]].<ref name="wapoVigilsAH">{{cite web |last1=Horton |first1=Alex |title=What it looks like in Charlottesville, site of a massive vigil and march |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2017/08/16/here-is-the-scene-in-charlottesville-site-of-a-massive-vigil-and-march/ |website=The Washington Post |accessdate=July 11, 2018 |language=en |date=August 16, 2017}}</ref>
=== Randall K. Cooper High School === Michael Wilson, Principal of the [[Randall K. Cooper High School]] that Fields had attended, said: "As educators, we are always using teachable moments and providing guidance to students to create college, career and life ready students to make good and sound choices. [...] We're all educators and we all are reflecting on what did we miss, or what could we do better. We do that with any student who may have made a wrong choice." He said that his staff sent thoughts and prayers to Charlottesville. Wilson said that the faculty members were worried about the victims and concerned about Fields.<ref name="cincinnati"/>
{{quote |text=And there are others like him out there – we as a society have to do a better job of figuring out how to reach them. This isn't something that happens overnight ... it builds up over time and we need to pay more attention to this. |author=Derek Weimer, Fields' history teacher at the Cooper High School |source=''[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]''<ref name="cincinnati"/> }}
Principal Wilson called Fields a "quiet and reserved student".<ref name="cincinnati" /> Fields was described as "shy" and "quiet" by his ex-classmates and neighbors.<ref name="blinder"/><ref name="cincinnati13">{{cite web|last1=Pilcher|first1=James|last2=Graves|first2=Chris|title=Ex-neighbor of James Alex Fields Jr.: 'Hope they put him where the sun doesn't shine'|url=https://eu.cincinnati.com/story/news/local/northern-ky/2017/08/13/former-classmate-neighbors-fields-seemed-shy-kept-himself/562917001/|website=The Cincinnati Enquirer|accessdate=May 26, 2018|language=en|date=August 13, 2017}}</ref> A woman who went to school with Fields told ''The New York Times'' that he "mostly kept to himself" and "didn't start fights or try to fight", but described him as "exceptionally odd and an outcast to be sure".<ref name="blinder" /> However, Fields' roommate on a class trip to Europe in 2015 told the Associated Press, "He had friends, he had people who would chat with him, it wasn't like he was an outcast."<ref name="cincinnatiPast" />
[[Boone County Schools]] spokeswoman Barbara Brady said that school officials "were not aware of any situation at Cooper High regarding Fields' behavior at the time of his enrollment". Brady questioned the trustworthiness of reports by Fields' ex-classmates, criticizing them for not reporting incidents.<ref name="cincinnatiPast"/>
{{quote |text=This is something I'm guilty of, too, I kind of brushed it off as just creepy. We thought it was all talk. No one ever thought he would do something so violent. |author=An ex-schoolmate |source=''The Cincinnati Enquirer''<ref name="cincinnatiPast"/> }}
=== Officials === The city of Charlottesville and its City Council published a statement: "This senseless act of violence rips a hole in our collective hearts. While it will never make up for the loss of a member of our community, we will pursue charges against the driver of the vehicle that caused her death and are confident justice will prevail."<ref name="hh"/><ref>[http://www.charlottesville.org/Home/Components/News/News/8422/635?npage=2 "A Statement of Condolence from the City of Charlottesville and City Council"]. The City of [[Charlottesville, Virginia]]. August 16, 2017. Retrieved October 1, 2018.</ref> Mayor [[Michael Signer]] called the attack domestic terrorism and blamed white supremacists.<ref name="vigilUSAT"/> In a statement on August 18, Mayor [[Michael Signer]] called on the City Council to "take concrete steps to memorialize Heather's name and legacy." Signer asked the governor to convene an emergency General Assembly session to allow Charlottesville to remove the statue of Robert E. Lee.<ref name="brotrumpnyt"/>
[[Brian Moran]], the [[Virginia Secretary of Public Safety]], said, "He was a terrorist to do what he did."<ref name="splscvc"/>
Attorney General Jeff Sessions said in a statement, "The violence and deaths in Charlottesville strike at the heart of American law and justice. When such actions arise from racial bigotry and hatred, they betray our core values and cannot be tolerated. Justice will prevail."<ref name="npr"/>
On August 17, [[White House Deputy Press Secretary]] [[Lindsay Walters]] said that Trump would meet with Heyer's family.<ref name="convenient">{{cite web |last1=Faulders |first1=Katherine |last2=Mallin |first2=Alexander |last3=Kelsey |first3=Adam |title=White House: Trump finding 'convenient' time to speak with Heyer's family |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/white-house-trump-finding-convenient-time-speak-charlottesville/story?id=49272806 |publisher=ABC News |accessdate=July 9, 2018 |language=en |date=August 18, 2017}}</ref>
==== President Trump ==== {{tweet |text = Condolences to the family of the young woman killed today, and best regards to all of those injured, in Charlottesville, Virginia. So sad! |name = Donald J. Trump |username = realDonaldTrump |date = August 13, 2017 |ID = 896512981319790592 }} {{tweet |text = Memorial service today for beautiful and incredible Heather Heyer, a truly special young woman. She will be long remembered by all! |name = Donald J. Trump |username = realDonaldTrump |date = August 16, 2017 |ID = 897834894822342656 }} U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] praised Heyer as "an incredible young woman".<ref name="wapoMemorial" /> Heyer's mother Susan Bro thanked Trump for his [[Unite the Right rally#Second statement|August 14 remarks]] on the event.<ref name="wapoMemorial" /> She wrote in a statement: "Thank you, President Trump, for those words of comfort and for denouncing those who promote violence and hatred. My condolences, also, to the grieving families of the two state troopers and quick recovery for those injured."<ref name="brotrumpnyt">{{cite web |last1=Bromwich |first1=Jonah Engel |title=Mother of Woman Killed in Charlottesville Says She Will Not Speak to Trump |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/18/us/politics/susan-bro-trump-heather-heyer.html |website=The New York Times |accessdate=July 9, 2018 |language=en |date=August 18, 2017}}</ref>
In the [[Unite the Right rally#Third statement|August 15 statement]], widely condemned as downplaying white supremacists, Trump said about Bro's statement on Trump's August 14 statement:<ref name="brotrumpnyt" /><ref name="convenient" />
{{Quote |text=I thought that the statement put out, the mother's statement, I thought was a beautiful statement. I'll tell you, it was something that I really appreciated. I thought it was terrific. And really, under the kind of stress that she's under, and the heartache she's under, I thought putting out that statement to me was really something I won't forget. Thank you all very much. Thank you. |author=Donald Trump }}
Bro initially declined to respond to Trump's August 15 statement as she was busy and tired.<ref name="wapoMemorial" /> After Bro saw Trump's August 15 statement, she said that she would not talk to Trump.<ref name="brotrumpnyt" />
Trump tweeted about the memorial service the morning of the day that it occurred.<ref name="wapoMemorial" /><ref name="convenient" /> No Trump administration officials were present at the service.<ref name="wapoMemorial" />
=== White nationalists === {{multiple image | total_width = 350 | image1 = Jason Kessler.jpg | alt1 = Jason Kessler | image2 = Richard b spencer cropped retouched.jpg | alt2 = Richard B. Spencer | footer = Jason Kessler and Richard B. Spencer | footer_align = center }} [[Jason Kessler]], the organizer of the Unite the Right rally, said that none of the organizers knew Fields.<ref name="nationalview" /> After being unable to hold a press conference due to violence, he accused the city of "shutting down" speech and said that the city officials "failed to separate the protest groups and were ill-equipped to handle the melee that resulted".<ref name="vigilUSAT" /> White supremacist rally speaker [[Richard B. Spencer]] placed the blame for the attack on authorities, who "failed to keep order". Spencer refused to condemn Fields, saying, "This man could have lost control because he felt in danger and slammed on the accelerator and unintentionally killed someone."<ref name="wapoBail"/>
On August 18, 2017, Kessler wrote on Twitter: "Heather Heyer was a fat, disgusting Communist. Communists have killed 94 million. Looks like it was payback time." Kessler deleted the tweet the next day, initially saying he was hacked, but later claiming he had been on a mixture of drugs. Other white nationalists criticized Kessler for the tweet, including Richard Spencer, who wrote: "I will no longer associate w/ Jason Kessler; no one should. Heyer's death was deeply saddening. 'Payback' is a morally reprehensible idea."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Pearce |first1=Matt |title=Tweet from the account of Charlottesville rally organizer insults slain protester Heather Heyer |url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-charlottesville-organizer-20170818-story.html |website=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=August 1, 2018 |date=August 19, 2017}}</ref>
=== Heyer's family members === Heyer's mother Susan Bro said that she did not want people to hate Fields.<ref name="SLwapo13" /> She said that it was not what her daughter would have wanted.<ref name="SLwapo13"/>
Heyer's father Mark said that "people on all sides need to learn to forgive each other".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gallop |first1=J. D. |last2=Denemark |first2=Malcolm |title='People need to stop hating,' father of Charlottesville victim Heather Heyer says |url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/08/14/charlottesville-protest-victim-father/564799001/ |website=USA Today |accessdate=August 1, 2018 |language=en |date=August 16, 2017}}</ref>
== Aftermath == [[File:Police block of crash site (36195158640).jpg|thumb|right|Police blocking the site of the crash]] On the last day of his job, photojournalist [[Ryan Kelly (photographer)|Ryan Kelly]] took a photograph of the attack for ''[[The Daily Progress]]'', the sole daily newspaper in the vicinity of Charlottesville. On April 16, 2018, Kelly won the [[Pulitzer Prize for Breaking News Photography]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Jenkins |first1=Aric |title=A Charlottesville Photographer Took His Tragic, Pulitzer Prize-Winning Shot on His Last Day. Now He Works for a Brewery |url=http://time.com/5242423/ryan-kelly-photograph-pulitzer-prize-charlottesville/ |website=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=July 11, 2018 |language=en |date=April 16, 2018}}</ref>
Photographer Jeremiah Knupp also took a photograph of the attack, working for ''[[The News Leader]]'', a daily newspaper serving [[Staunton, Virginia]] and the surrounding areas. Knupp took the photograph from a pole on the parking garage, south-west of the intersection of Water Street and Fourth Street Southeast.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cavallaro |first1=Gabe |title=Photo shows fatal attack on pedestrians with car |url=https://eu.newsleader.com/story/news/local/2017/08/12/photo-shows-car-attack-pedestrians/562232001/ |website=[[The News Leader]] |accessdate=August 11, 2018 |language=en |date=August 13, 2017}}</ref>
A [[GoFundMe]] campaign created to support Heyer's family had surpassed {{USD|200000}} in a day.<ref name="hh"/> Fundraising websites removed campaigns that had sought to fund Fields' [[legal defense fund|legal defense]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Dang |first1=Sheila |title=Crowdfunding sites refuse to raise money for white nationalists |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/charlottesville-latest-james-alex-field-crowdfunding-white-nationalists-kkk-neo-nazis-gofundme-a7893891.html |website=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=July 9, 2018 |date=August 15, 2017}}</ref> The [[Democratic Socialists of America]] quickly raised {{USD|198000}}, but were criticized for the convoluted application process for victims and timeliness in addressing their applications. The money raised was eventually transferred to the [[National Compassion Fund]] for management and disbursement.<ref name="dsamoney">{{cite web |last1=Newton |first1=Creede |title=Charlottesville: Where's the $200,000 the DSA raised? |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/12/charlottesville-200000-dsa-raised-171204165738796.html |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] |accessdate=3 August 2018 |date=7 December 2017 |quote=Clarification Dec. 7, 2017: This article has been amended to make clear the National Compassion Fund controls and is responsible for the disbursement of funds, after concerns were raised by the DSA.}}</ref>
Heyer's mother Susan Bro started the nonprofit Heather Heyer Foundation. It was funded from the GoFundMe campaign and from new donations. Bro said that the foundation would be devoted to civil rights and provide scholarships to people who want [[social justice]].<ref name="alcindorHHF">{{cite web |last1=Alcindor |first1=Yamiche |title=Foundation Started by Charlottesville Victim's Mother Promotes Social Justice |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/26/us/politics/foundation-started-by-charlottesville-victims-mother-promotes-social-justice.html |website=The New York Times |accessdate=July 9, 2018 |language=en |date=August 26, 2017}}</ref> She quit her job as a secretary and bookkeeper for a Virginia Cooperative Extension office after the attack, and became the president and chair of the board of the Heather Heyer Foundation.<ref name="way">{{cite web|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2017/12/19/heather-heyer-susan-bro-charlottesville-street-dedication/967470001/|title=Charlottesville victim Heather Heyer's mother to speak at street dedication|date=December 20, 2017|accessdate=July 31, 2018|agency=The Associated Press}}</ref>
On August 15, 2017, Tadrint and Micah Washington, who were in the white sedan that was hit during the attack, filed a US$3 million lawsuit in damages against Jason Kessler, James Alex Fields Jr., Richard Spencer and 30 other groups and individuals.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Berg |first1=Lauren |title=$3M lawsuit filed against Kessler, Fields and others after fatal crash |url=https://www.dailyprogress.com/news/local/m-lawsuit-filed-against-kessler-fields-and-others-after-fatal/article_a024d09c-81ea-11e7-992f-c3882c7102c9.html |website=The Daily Progress |accessdate=August 1, 2018 |language=en |date=August 15, 2017}}</ref>
In September 2017, [[New York's 25th State Assembly district|New York's 25th Assembly district]] Representative [[Nily Rozic]], a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], filed a bill and petitioned the [[New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation]] to rename the [[Donald J. Trump State Park]] in honor of Heyer.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Shugerman |first1=Emily |title=A New York politician is campaigning to rename Trump park after Heather Heyer |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-park-heather-heyer-petition-rename-democrat-campaign-nily-rozic-a7934806.html |website=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=July 11, 2018 |date=September 7, 2017}}</ref>
On December 20, 2017, a part of Fourth Street Southeast in Charlottesville, where the attack occurred, was designated Honorary Heather Heyer Way.<ref name="way" />
On the afternoon of May 12, 2018, Heyer's close friend Marissa Blair married her fiancé Marcus Martin, who pushed her out of the car's way and was injured in the attack himself.<ref name="marriageNYT">{{cite web |last1=La Gorce |first1=Tammy |title=Months After a Brutal Day in Charlottesville, a Tender Wedding |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/16/fashion/weddings/charlottesville-protester-wedding.html |website=The New York Times |accessdate=July 11, 2018 |language=en |date=May 16, 2018}}</ref> During the ceremony, Bro led a butterfly release in remembrance of Heyer.<ref name="marriageUSAT">{{cite web |last1=Bowerman |first1=Mary |title=Couple who survived Charlottesville attack get married in service dedicated to slain friend |url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/05/18/couple-hurt-charlottesville-attack-marry-remember-heather-heyer/622270002/ |website=[[USA Today]] |accessdate=July 11, 2018 |language=en |date=May 18, 2018}}</ref>
Susan Bro presented the 2017 [[MTV Video Music Award for Best Fight Against the System]].<ref name="alcindorHHF" />
The 2018 film ''[[BlacKkKlansman]]'' features video footage of the attack; the film ends with a dedication to Heyer.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Park |first1=Andrea |title=Spike Lee slams Trump at Cannes, talks about using Heather Heyer's death scene in new film |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/spike-lee-slams-trump-at-cannes-blackkklansman-premiere-charlottesville-heather-heyer/ |publisher=[[CBS News]] |accessdate=July 11, 2018 |language=en |date=May 16, 2018}}</ref>

{{no footnotes|date=August 2012}} {{Lead too long|date=June 2017}} [[Image:Cochimi map.png|right]]
The '''Cochimí''' were the aboriginal inhabitants of the central part of the [[Baja California peninsula]], from [[El Rosario, Baja California|El Rosario]] in the north to [[San Javier, Baja California Sur|San Javier]] in the south.
They spoke a set of dialects or closely related languages that have been classified in a variety of ways. The most prominent division, between Northern Cochimí and Southern Cochimí, has generally been put to the south of San Ignacio (Mixco 1978, 1979, 2006; Laylander 1997). At one time designated "Peninsular Yuman", Cochimí bears an evident relationship to the [[Yuman languages]] of northern Baja California, southern California, and western Arizona. Mauricio J. Mixco (1978, 2006) reassessed this relationship and judged it to be too distant for Cochimí to be included within the Yuman family proper. He placed Cochimí as a sister language to the Yuman family, thus forming the Yuman–Cochimí family.
The Cochimí were first encountered by Spanish seaborne explorers during the sixteenth century, including [[Francisco de Ulloa|Ulloa]], [[Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo|Cabrillo]], [[Sebastián Vizcaíno|Vizcaíno]], and others. Sporadic encounters continued until the [[Jesuits]] established missions on the peninsula in the late seventeenth century. [[Eusebio Kino|Eusebio Francisco Kino]] made an abortive foundation at [[Misión San Bruno|San Bruno]], to the north of Loreto, in 1683-1685. [[Juan María de Salvatierra]] began the first successful mission in 1697 at [[Misión de Nuestra Señora de Loreto Conchó|Loreto]] among the [[Monqui]], who were southern neighbors of the Cochimí. This was quickly followed by [[Francisco María Píccolo|Francesco Maria Piccolo's]] Cochimí mission at [[Misión San Francisco Javier de Viggé-Biaundó|San Javier]] in 1699. Over the next seven decades, the frontier of Jesuit control over the Cochimí gradually extended northward, with missions at [[Misión Santa Rosalía de Mulegé|Mulegé]] (1705, [[Misión San José de Comondú|Comondú]] (1708), [[Misión La Purísima Concepción de Cadegomó|La Purísima]] (1720), [[Misión Nuestra Señora de Guadalupe de Huasinapi|Guadalupe]] (1720), [[Misión San Ignacio Kadakaamán|San Ignacio]] (1728), [[Misión Santa Gertrudis|Santa Gertrudis]] (1751), [[Misión San Francisco Borja|San Borja]] (1762), and [[Misión Santa María de los Ángeles|Santa María]] (1767). After the Spanish crown expelled the Jesuits from Baja California in 1768, the [[Franciscans]] under [[Junípero Serra]] established an additional mission at [[Misión San Fernando Rey de España de Velicatá|San Fernando Velicatá]] (1769) on their way north to Alta California. The Franciscans' successors in Baja California, the [[Dominican Order|Dominicans]], created the final new mission among the Cochimí at [[Misión Nuestra Señora del Santísimo Rosario de Viñacado|El Rosario]] (1774). Decimated by epidemics of Old World diseases, the Cochimí population declined, until sometime in the nineteenth or possibly the early twentieth century their language and traditional culture became extinct.
The Cochimí were hunter-gatherers, without agriculture or metallurgy. Pottery-making may have reached the northern Cochimí before Spanish contact ([[Malcolm Jennings Rogers|Rogers]] 1945). Their material culture was generally simple, but it suited their arid environment and mobile lifestyle. The highest level of social organization was the autonomous local community, and inter-community conflicts appear to have been frequent. Among the unusual cultural traits noted for the Cochimí and some of their neighbors were the second harvest of the pitahaya, the ''maroma'', wooden ''tablas'', and human-hair capes:
* The fruit of [[Pitahaya|pitahaya]] cactus provided a highly valued but short-lived [[seasonal food]] resource. Subsequent to the pitahaya harvest, Baja Californians winnowed undigested pitahaya seeds from their own dried excrement and then roasted and ate this "second harvest". * Another unusual food trait was the ''maroma''. A valued morsel of meat was tied with a string, swallowed, then pulled back up and passed to the next person in a circle of consumers, until the meat finally disintegrated. * ''Tablas'' were wooden tablets with painted designs and/or drilled holes, used in religious ceremonies. Some of these artifacts have been found archaeologically (Massey 1972; Hedges 1973; [[Peveril Meigs|Meigs]] 1974). * Capes made from donated human hair were worn by shamans on ceremonial occasions ([[Peveril Meigs|Meigs]] 1970).
Information on Cochimí customs and beliefs has been preserved in the brief observations by explorers but, above all, in the writings of the Jesuits (Aschmann 1959; Laylander 2000; [[W. Michael Mathes|Mathes]] 2006). Particularly important and detailed are the works of [[Miguel Venegas]] (1757, 1979) and [[Miguel del Barco]] (1973).
==Language== {{see also|Yuman–Cochimí languages|Languages of Mexico}} The [[Cochimí language]] was part of the [[Yuman–Cochimí languages|Yuman–Cochimí]] family.
