{{about|the status of women's rights|the Iranian women's movement|Women's rights movement in Iran}} {{Lead too short|date=January 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Women in society sidebar}}
[[Women's rights|Women's rights]] in Iran have changed according to the form of government ruling the state. With the rise of each regime, a series of mandates for women's rights arose, which affected a broad range of issues from voting rights to dress code.<ref name=":010">{{Cite journal|last=Camara|first=Andrea|date=April 22, 2018|title=Women's Rights in Iran during the Years of Shah, Ayatollah Khomeini, and Khamenei|url=|journal=Stars|volume=|pages=5–60|via=}}</ref>
For Iranian women, their rights and legal status have changed since the early 20th century. Women's rights in Iran are limited compared to the women in developed nations. The [[World Economic Forum]]’s 2017 [[Global Gender Gap Report|Global Gender Gap]] Report ranked Iran 140 out of 144 countries for gender parity. Women in Iran constitute 19% of the workforce in 2017 with only 7% growth since 1990.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.weforum.org/reports/the-global-gender-gap-report-2017|title=World Economic Forum|last=|first=|date=2018-04-17|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The legal rights of women have gone through many changes during the past three political regimes in Iran. During the [[Qajar dynasty|Qajar]], the royal dynasty that ruled Iran from the late 1800s to the early 20th century, women were more isolated as they were not engaged in politics, and their economic contribution was limited to household work. These conditions transformed to a great extent during the [[Pahlavi dynasty|Pahlavi regime]] from 1925-1979 where women had much more freedom, but that freedom soon retracted after the [[Iranian Revolution|Iranian revolution]] in 1979.<ref name=":010"/>
During the Qajar and soon after the beginning of the [[Islam]]ic revolution, the status of women in society was equal to second-class citizens.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Razavi|first=Shahra|date=2006|title=Islamic Politics, Human Rights and Women's Claims for Equality in Iran|jstor=4017751|journal=Third World Quarterly|volume=7|pages=1223–1237}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Painting santur.jpg|thumb|Women playing music in the [[Safavid dynasty|Safavi era]] ]] Historical records dating back to the great [[Achaemenid Empire]] (2000 – 550 BCE), women in [[Iran]] have, for the most part, been subordinate to men.
Iran's history is commonly divided into three segments: Pre-Islamic, post-Islamic, and the modern era. Though little is known about Iran's pre-Islamic time, the recorded history starts with the Achaemenid Empire in 2000 B.C. During the rule of the Achaemenid Empire, Greek historical accounts include that women were able to participate in civic affairs; however, this participation was still limited and considered unusual to the general population. Greek historian, [[Herodotus]], after his visit to the Achaemenian Empire, recounted that Persian men and women worked together in managing the affairs of the states and participated in public ceremony together. Royal women had access to education, were trained horse riders, and participated in official ceremonies, such as the King's birthday and [[Nowruz|Naw-ruz]], the annual Persian New Year.<ref name=":26">{{Cite journal|last=Jomepour|first=Rahele|date=2015|title=Women in Iran: Ancient History to Modern Times, and Back|url=|journal=Iowa State University|volume=|pages=6–49|via=}}</ref>
After the fall of the Achaemenid Empire and the rise of [[Sasanian Empire|Sassanid Empire]], women's position in Iran degraded and their status was inferior to men. During this era, elite women veiled themselves as a form of protection from non-elite men.<ref name=":26"/>
=== The Persian Constitutional Revolution === During the Qajar and soon at the beginning of the [[Iranian Revolution|Islamic revolution]] “most women in Persian were second-class citizens with limited if any, rights such as to inheritance or to obtain a basic education. For example, tribal and nomadic groups (like the [[Kurds]], [[Bakhtiari people|Bakhtiari]], [[Qashqai people|Qashqai]]) allowed their women to interact with men to a certain extent, and even some considered polygamy and Mu’ta (Shia temporary marriage) as undesirable.”<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Islamic politics, human rights and women's claims for equality in Iran|last=Burki|first=Shireen|publisher=Third World Quarterly|year=2006|isbn=|location=|pages=177–180}}</ref>
Iranian women played a significant role in the [[Persian Constitutional Revolution]] of 1905–11. They participated in large numbers in public affairs and held important positions in journalism and in schools and associations that flourished from 1911 to 1924.<ref name="ReferenceA">Afary, Janet (1996). ''The Iranian Constitutional Revolution, 1906–1911: Grassroots democracy, social democracy, and the origins of feminism''. Columbia University Press, New York {{ISBN|9780231103510}}</ref> Prominent Iranian women who played a vital part in the revolution include [[Bibi Khatoon Astarabadi]], [[Noor-ol-Hoda Mangeneh]], [[Mohtaram Eskandari]], [[Sediqeh Dowlatabadi]], and [[Qamar ol-Molouk Vaziri]].
At the turn of the 20th century, many educated Persian women were attracted to journalism and writing. ''Danesh'' (1907) was the first specialized journal focusing on women's issues. Later, ''[[Shokufeh (magazine)|Shokoufeh]]'', ''Nameie Banovan'', ''Alam e Nesvan'', and ''Nesvan e Vatan Khah'' were published in [[Tehran]]. Moreover, ''Nesvan e Shargh'' in [[Bandar Anzali]], ''Jahan e Zanan'' in [[Mashhad]], ''Dokhtaran e Iran'' in [[Shiraz]], and ''Peik e saadat'' in [[Rasht]] addressed women's issues throughout [[Iran|Persia]] (Iran). Although the defeat of the [[Constitutionalist Party of Iran|constitutionalists]] (1921–25) and the consolidation of power by [[Reza Shah]] (1925–41) destroyed the women's journals and groups, the state during these years implemented social reforms such as mass education and paid employment for women. Reza Shah also began his controversial policy of ''[[Kashf-e hijab|Kashf-e-Hijab]]'', which banned the wearing of the Islamic [[hijab]] in public. But like other sectors of society in the years under Reza Shah's rule, women lost the right to express themselves, and dissent was repressed.<ref>[http://www.iranian.com/Opinion/2004/June/MK/index.html Two sides of the same coin]</ref>
=== Pahlavi era === [[File:Atomic women Iran.JPG|thumb|Iranian newspaper clip from 1968 reads: "A quarter of Iran's Nuclear Energy scientists are women."]] In 1925, the military commander, Reza Khan, overthrew the Qajar dynasty. In the same year, he was declared the Shah of Iran, which marked the beginning of the [[Pahlavi dynasty|Pahlavi]] era. Iran's societal structure and the status of women began to improve after the Shah went on a visit to Turkey in 1936. The Shah was inspired by the modernization that was taking place there by the Turkish leader, [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk|Atatürk]]. In a speech he gave upon his return from Turkey, the former Shah of Iran said: “I am extremely delighted that women have become aware of their rights and entitlement… Now women are on their way to gain other rights in addition to the great privilege of motherhood.”<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Politics of State Intervention: Gender Politics in Pakistan, Afghanistan, and Iran|last=Burki|first=Shireen|publisher=Lexington Books|year=2013|isbn=|location=|pages=170–180}}</ref>
After Reza Shah was banished to the [[Morris Island]] by the Allied powers, his son, [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi|Mohammad Reza]], took over. The Shah's government began its White Revolution in 1962 and ratified essential women's rights measures, including suffrage and the Family Protection Law of 1967.<ref name=":26"/> The Shah's White Revolution helped to increase the legal rights of women.<ref name=":010"/> In 1975, this law was amended to be more heavily in favor of women, by ending extrajudicial divorce and restricting polygamy. It also raised the minimum age of marriage of girls from 13-15 to 18.<ref name=":26"/>
===Islamic Republic=== {{Main|Women in Iran}}
==== Women and the Iranian Revolution ====
When the [[Iranian Revolution]] started in 1977, many women protested by marching in metropolitan cities and wore chadors as a sign of protest. Women played a significant role in the success of the revolution.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Khaz Ali|first=Anisa|date=July 2010|title=Iranian Women After the Islamic Revolution|url=http://conflictsforum.org/briefings/IranianWomenAfterIslamicRev.pdf.|journal=A Conflicts Forum Monograph|volume=|pages=4–20|via=}}</ref> Their role was both praised and encouraged by the revolutionary leader, Ayatollah [[Ruhollah Khomeini|Khomeini]], who in various speeches stated:
* "Our uprising is indebted to women. Men took the example of the women into the streets. Women encouraged the men to revolt, and sometimes even led the way. Woman is a wonderful creature. She possesses fiendish, strong [and] passionate capabilities." <ref name=":3" />(Imam Khomeini, 6/5/1980) * The Revolution transformed Iranian society, and women were the pioneers of this transformation.<ref name=":3" />(Ayatollah Khomeini, 30/3/1982) * We must not forget the activities which women performed, notably confrontations. Iranian women were able to turn into a revolutionary, political, conscious fighting element through their conscious faith ... Truly, women never lagged behind in any area or on any battleground.<ref name=":3" /> (Ayatollah Khomeini, 6/3/1987)
Because the first Pahlavi Shah banned the use of the hijab, many women decided to show their favor for the Islamic revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Khomeini, by wearing a chador, thinking that this would be the best way to show their support without having to be vocal.<ref name=":62">{{Cite journal|last=Kurzman|first=Charles|date=2008|title=A feminist generation in iran|url=|journal=Iranian studies|volume=3|pages=297–321|via=}}</ref>
Women took part in the Iranian revolution by participating in the protests. Organizations supportive of the Islamic Revolution, such as [[Mujahideen|Mujahidin]], welcomed women into their organization and gave women essential tasks. Ayatollah Khomeini also encouraged women to take part in the protest against the Shah.<ref name=":010"/>
==== Khomeini's era ====
With the rise of Ayatollah Khomeini, women's roles were limited as they were encouraged to raise large families and tend to household duties. Khomeini believed this to be the most vital role women could pursue. It was this belief that led to the closing of women's centers, childcare centers and the abolishment of family planning initiatives.<ref name=":010"/>
====Post-Khomeini era==== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Zanane iran.JPG|thumb|Iranian notable women: [[Simin Behbahani]], [[Shirin Ebadi]], [[Tahmineh Milani]], [[Mehrangiz Kar]], [[Elaheh Koulaei]], and [[Farah Karimi]]. [[Women's rights movement in Iran|The women's movement]] during the [[Iranian revolution|revolution]], and in post-revolution Iran continued to be strong. Perhaps the most notable figure{{deletable image-caption|Sunday, 11 November 2012}}]] --> After the passing of Ayatollah Khomeini, women put more pressure on the government to grant more rights to women. [[Ali Khamenei|Khamenei]], who followed Khomeini took a more liberal approach and enabled women's advancement by reopening the women's centers and restoring many of the laws that were abdicated after the revocation of Family Protection Laws.<ref name=":010"/>
In May 1997, the overwhelming majority of women voted for [[Mohammad Khatami]], a reformist cleric who promised more political freedom. His election brought a period during which women became increasingly bold in expressing ideas, demands, and criticisms. The awarding of the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] to [[Shirin Ebadi]], an Iranian human rights and women's right activist, further emboldened women's rights activists inside Iran and cemented their relationships with Iranian feminists abroad.
During the Sixth [[Majlis of Iran|Parliament]], some of Iran's strongest advocates of women's rights emerged. Almost all of the 11 female lawmakers of the (at the time) 270-seat Majlis tried to change some of Iran's more conservative laws. However, during the [[Iranian legislative election, 2004|elections for the Seventh Majlis]], the all-male [[Council of Guardians]] banned the 11 women from running for office, and only conservative females were allowed to run. The Seventh Majlis reversed many of the laws passed by the reformist Sixth Majlis.
== Legal rights == During Mohammad Reza Shah's era, women were given the right to divorce or sue for divorce and also gained the right to vote. [[Abortion]] also became a right for women in cases such as rape. It was during this period that segregation laws were lifted and men and women were allowed to associate in public together.<ref name=":26"/>
Most initiatives concerning women's rights during the Pahlavi dynasty began with the White Revolution in 1962, which eventually led to the enfranchisement of women. This enfranchisement came from the Prime Minister Asadollah Alam. Most revolutionary initiatives came with the White Revolution. A law was passed which gave women limited voting rights, allowing them the right to vote in local elections.<ref name=":010"/>
Protests led by Ayatollah Khomeini regarding voting rights resulted in the repeal of the law. Khomeini believed that such power for women was comparable to prostitution.<ref name=":010"/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shoaee|first=Rokhsareh S|date=1987|title=The Mujahid Women of Iran|url=|journal=The Middle East Journal|volume=|pages=519–537}}</ref>
Since the voting rights law was repealed, women were not allowed to take part in a referendum held during the White Revolution. However, the Minister of Agriculture suggested that women's movement leaders set up a voting booth to voice their suggestions. Though their votes did not count, the high number of women votes convinced Mohammad Reza Shah to grant women voting rights soon after the referendum. In September of the same year, 1963, in the parliamentary elections, six women were elected to the parliament, and two women were appointed by the Shah to serve in the Senate.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Esfandiari|first=Haleh|date=1997|title=Women and Iran's Islamic Revolution|url=|journal=Reconstructed Lives|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
===Hijab=== {{See also|Hijab}} [[File:Basiji Students meeting with Supreme Leader of Iran, Ali Khamenei - September 4, 1999 (1).jpg|thumb|Two [[Basij]]i women with Hijab]] Hijab is a veil worn by [[Muslim]] women when interacting with males outside of their immediate family. Before the rise of the Achaemenian empire, women were not forced to wear a veil. In 1935, Reza Shah mandated that women should no longer be veiled in public.<ref name=":26"/>
After Reza Shah mandated women to appear in public unveiled in 1935, a significant number of women became isolated in their houses as they felt going outside their home with no Hijab was equivalent to being naked. Women's dependency during this period grew as they relied on others to run errands. The unveiling law did not last long. When Mohammad Reza rose to power, he abdicated this law, and the hijab became an individual decision.<ref name=":42">{{Cite journal|last=Tafreshi|first=Poupak|date=January 2010|title=The Struggle for Freedom, Justice, and Equality: The History of the Journey of Iraninan Women in the Last Century|url=|journal=Washington University Open Scholarship|volume=|pages=1–98|via=}}</ref>
Compulsory Hijab was re-instated for Iranian state employees after the Islamic revolution in 1979 followed by a law for compulsory Hijab in all public spaces in 1983.<ref name=":42"/> On 26 November,2018 [[Nasrin Sotoudeh]], a female political prisoner at Tehran’s Evin Prison started a hunger strike demanding the release of [[Farhad Meysami]] a doctor who is in jail for protesting compulsory hijab.<ref>[https://en.radiofarda.com/a/iran-rights-actvist-stoudeh-starts-hunger-strike-meysami/29623512.html Prominent Rights Activist Goes On Hunger Strike In Iran Prison]</ref>
===Sexual law and zina===
'''Zina''' is an [[Sharia|Islamic legal]] term referring to unlawful sexual intercourse.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Semerdjian|first=Elyse|date=2009|title=The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Islamic World|url=|journal=Oxford: Oxford University Press|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> In the Iranian penal code of 1991, [[extramarital sex]] ([[zina]]) is punishable by [[stoning]] or [[Cutting|slashing]]. An entire chapter of Iranian penal code deals with [[punishment]]s for extramarital sex. Another chapter details how such relations can be proved and verified in the court.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Boe|first=Marianne|date=2015|title=Family Law in Contemporary Iran: Women's Rights Activism and Shari'a|url=|journal=International library of Iranian Studies|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
===Marriage law===
As part of the White Revolution, Mohammad Reza Shah also enacted the Family Protection Laws. These were a series of laws that included women's rights to divorce, helped to raise the marriage age for both boys and girls, and curtailed the custom of polygamy, mandating spousal consent before lawfully marrying a second wife.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mahdi|first=Ali|date=October 2012|title=The Iranian Women's Movement: A Century Long Struggle.|url=|journal=The Muslim World|volume=94|pages=427–48}}</ref>
Under these laws, the right of divorce for women was granted by allowing women to put an end to a marriage if they were unhappy. The law also gave the right to women to keep custody of their children. In addition, it gave women the right to an abortion under certain circumstances, such as rape and if the woman's life was at risk.<ref name=":010"/>
In 2008, President [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]]'s administration introduced a "family support bill" in the parliament that would have allowed men to marry a second wife without his first wife's permission and put a tax on ''Mariyeh'' – which is seen by many women "as a financial safety net in the event a husband leaves the marriage and is not forced to pay alimony."<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|title=Iranian Parliament Delays Vote on Bill That Upset Judiciary, Women's Activists|last=Erdbring|first=Thomas|date=September 2008|work=Washington Post}}</ref> In September 2008, however, the bill for the tax was returned by Iran's judiciary to the legislative council with complaints about the polygamy and tax articles,and these were removed from the bill.<ref name=":5" />
During the Ahmadinejad administration, ''Siqeh'', or temporary marriages (that can last from 30 minutes to a lifetime), was used, especially in response to the financial demands of prenuptial agreements. The temporary marriages, enacted by ''[[fatwa]]'' in 1983 under Khomeini, are heavily criticized as a form of legalized prostitution.[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-Chron-4|<sup>[4]</sup>]][[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-Siq1-21|<sup href="fatwa">[21]</sup>]][[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-query.nytimes.com-22|<sup>[22]</sup>]]
===Divorce law===
Divorce law in the Islamic republic of Iran was initially based upon the general rule in Shari'a law that gives men the sole right to end a marriage at any time. This is based on Article 1133 of the previous Civil Code (1928) that states: A man can divorce his wife whenever he wishes to do so.[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-iranhrdc.org-23|<sup>[23]</sup>]]
This law in the Iranian constitution was modified in 1967 by the Family Protection Act which granted women more rights regarding divorce and established mandatory procedures regarding divorce. This also served as an amendment that made all private divorces illegal."[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-iranhrdc.org-23|<sup href="Mahmoud Ahmadinejad">[23]</sup>]]
More divorce rights were given to women, including the right to apply for a divorce under specific conditions. Article 1130 of the [[Civil code|Civil Code]] gave the court more power to grant a judicial divorce requested by a woman as well as providing specific circumstances in which the wife can attain power of attorney and expedite the divorce process.[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-iranhrdc.org-23|<sup href="File:First Iranian women university.jpg">[23]</sup>]]
In modern Iran, divorce can be obtained by both men and women, and the custody of children is given to women rather than men.<ref name=":010"/>
=== Civil law ===
Iran's civil law system can be seen as very gender distinct, with numerous laws pertaining to favor men over women and few, if any, laws favoring women. Iran follows strict Islamic laws. One of the civil laws that is recognized in Iran is the legal age of puberty. In Iran, children that reach the age of puberty also gain penal responsibility, meaning that once a child has surpassed the age of puberty, he or she is legally tried as an adult. This can be seen as disadvantageous towards women, as female children reach puberty around the age of ten and boys around the age of fourteen. This means that girls as young as the age of ten can be prosecuted criminally. Punishments can vary from prison sentences to lashes and, rarely, the death penalty.[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-24|<sup href="geography">[24]</sup>]]
Laws in Iran forces gender equality to be practically non-existent. Women continue to face mistreatment, especially by law enforcement officers. An example of this would be the mass amount of violence against women during the [[2009 Iranian presidential election]], where many women were arrested for voting for [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]]. One anonymous woman recollected what happened in prison, and said that one of the prison guards told her, “I will do something you will never forget. I'll make it so you never want to leave your house again, so any time you hear my name, you will tremble." In the end, these women's votes were never counted. [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] won the election by a landslide and, as a result, massive protests against this election occurred, saying that the election was a fraud. Ahmadinejad took office regardless.[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-25|<sup href="Iranian society">[25]</sup>]]
==Education== [[File:First Iranian women university.jpg|thumb|350px|First group of women who entered university, 1936.<ref>بدرالملوک بامداد، زن ایرانی از انقلاب مشروطه تا انقلاب سفید. تهران: ابن‌سینا، ۱۳۴۷. ص ۹۹</ref>]] {{See also|Higher education in Iran|Science in Iran}}
Female education in Iran is a relatively recent advancement in society. Women have been allowed to attend school as of the late 19th century and have been allowed to attend college for merely 80 years. During the Qajar years, two schools were opened for girls, both of which were opened by missionaries for minority girls such as [[Christian]], [[Jews|Jew]], and [[Zoroastrianism|Zoroastrian]] girls. Among the elite families, some provided their daughters with education through private tutors, but, for the most part, Muslim girls were denied education as the clergies feared female education would negatively impact the fabric of Islamic society. For the pious and faithful Muslim women, education was only acceptable when it was in agreement with the teachings of Islam. The first school for Muslim girls opened at the end of 19th century in 1899. Women's education began to increase by 1920 as 58 schools in Tehran provided education for nearly 3,000 girls.<ref name=":72">{{Cite journal|last=Zahedifar|first=Effat|date=Spring 2012|title=Women in Higher Education in Iran|url=http://www.duo.uio.no|journal=DUO UIO|volume=|pages=5–75|via=}}</ref>
During the reign of Mohammad Reza Shah and his western development model and policies, women's education accelerated much more rapidly during the 1960s and 1970s. Before the fall of his dynasty, women's enrollment in universities was just over 30 percent.<ref name=":72"/>
When Khomeini reached power in 1979, under his rule, the government began to Islamisize the Shah's westernized education system. To do this, they began purifying it to be culturally and religiously aligned with the new Islamic regime in Iran. The options for what women could study was halved, as the goal of purification of the Shah's education system was to help the new system meet the needs of the society. Women were no longer able to study the following fields: veterinary medicine, geology, agricultural sciences, animal husbandry, and natural resources. These limitations were slowly lifted through lobbying efforts. By the end of the 20th century, all the limitations were lifted, and women were able to begin studying in these various fields. However, higher education was still male dominated.<ref name=":72"/>
Educational opportunities increased through the rule of Mohammad Khatami, who served as President of Iran from 1997-2005. Khatami viewed the home as the proper setting for Iranian women, yet did not seek to exclude women from participating in the public sphere.<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|title=The Paradox of Tradition and Modernity in Female Education in the Islamic Republic of Iran|last=Mehran|first=Golnar|publisher=Comparative Education Review|year=2003|issn=0010-4086|location=|pages=269–286}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite book|title=Women, Power, and Politics in 21st Century Iran|last=Povey and Rostami-Povey|first=Tara and Elaheh|publisher=Ashgate Publishing|year=2012|isbn=1409402053|location=|pages=42–55}}</ref> Noting the increasing dominance of women in higher education, Khatami stated that though the increase was concerning, he did not wish to create obstacles to reduce this participation. Khatami called for an opening of majors and specialties for women in universities and an end to the quota system, which was introduced after the Islamic revolution in Iran to put a cap on women's entrance to universities.<ref name=":9" />
At the beginning of Khatami's presidency, over 95 percent of girls in Iran attended elementary school.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women and Politics in the Islamic Republic of Iran|last=Vakil|first=Sanam|publisher=Bloombury publishing|year=2011|isbn=1441105166|location=|pages=}}</ref> In 1997-98, 38.2 percent of Iranian women enrolled in higher education. This number rose to 47.2 percent by 2000.<ref name=":9" /> As female enrollment in schooling continued to climb, the segregation of the sexes in academic specialization continued to persist through the end of the 1990s. In the 1998-99 academic year, males dominated enrollment in math-physics at 58% and technical fields with 71% of secondary school students. Women disproportionately enrolled in the humanities and the experimental sciences at 61% of the enrollment.<ref name=":8" /> Gender specialization continued through the university level where a majority of women studied in the fields of basic sciences, medical sciences, and arts. Agriculture, veterinary science, engineering, and humanities were pursued mostly by men.<ref name=":8" /> Overall, however, the decade was characterized by a three-fold increase in female enrollment in higher education.<ref name=":62"/>
The statistics of the Khatami presidency show the slow rise of female participation in education. Women pursuing teaching positions in higher education also made gains during this period, as women held nearly half of all assistant professorships at universities, nearly double that held a decade before.<ref name=":10">{{Cite book|title=Women and Higher Education in Iran|last=Rezai-Rashti|first=Goli-Moghadam, Valentine|publisher=International Review of Education|year=2011|ISSN=0020-8566|location=|pages=419–441}}</ref> However, the number of women accepted into tenure-track and full-time professorships in 2001-02 remained low at 17.3%, which is disproportionate to the number of educated women in Iranian society.<ref name=":10" />
Male-dominated fields were overtaken by females as female numbers dramatically increased in the medical fields from 51% female versus 49% male.<ref name=":72"/>
Data shows that nearly 80% of Iranian women are literate, but only 21% of these women are employed. In contrast, 85% of males are literate, and 79% of them are employed. In total, 40% of educated women are unemployed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iranlaborreport.com/?p=895|title=Iranian Women Labor Woes|last=|first=|date=May 2009|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=April 26, 2018}}</ref>
Over the past two decades, the number of women attending university institutions has multiplied. This rapid increase has caused concerns for the Iranian officials. In 2009, [[Islamic Consultative Assembly|Iranian parliament]] (Majlis) questioned if they need to establish a quota for the number of women entering public colleges. The conservatives believe that the increase in women's access to higher education is contrary to Islamic values and can threaten the traditional family structure that forms the basis of Islamic society.<ref name=":72"/>
Despite all the improvement and advancement made concerning higher education for women, there have been many ups and downs regarding this issue. On August 6, 2012, the Mehr News Agency in Iran “posted a bulletin that 36 universities in the country had excluded women from 77 fields of study". This was part of an effort by the parliament to put a quota on women's participation in higher education.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shirazi|first=Faegheh|date=September 2014|title=Educating Iranian Women|url=|journal=International Journal of Education and Social Science|volume=2|pages=1–15|via=}}</ref>
The increase in women's enrollment in some fields is more apparent than others. For example, in 2008, 66% of students in medical sciences were women.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":72"/>
The writer and activist [[Bibi Khatoon Astarabadi]] founded the first school for Persian girls in 1907. In this school, Iranian women could study a variety of subjects, including history, [[geography]], law, [[calculus]], religion, and cooking.
[[Women's rights movement in Iran|Iranian women rights activists]] determined that [[education]] was a key for [[Iranian women]] and [[Iranian society|society]]. They argued that giving women education was best for Iran, in that the mothers would raise better sons for their country.<ref>Sanasarian, Eliz (1982). The Women's Rights Movements in Iran. New York: Praeger. pp. 124–129. {{ISBN|0-03-059632-7}}.</ref>
Enrollment of 12 women into the [[Tehran University]] in 1936, marked the entry of women into university education in Iran.<ref>[http://www.iranchamber.com/history/articles/ancient_medicine_mesopotamia_iran.php ''History of Medicine in Iran'']</ref>
As of 2006, women account for well over half of the university students in Iran<ref name=BBCed>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/5359672.stm Women graduates challenge Iran], Francis Harrison, [[BBC]], September 26, 2006. Retrieved September 21, 2008.</ref> and 70% of Iran's science and engineering students.<ref>[http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v444/n7115/full/444022a.html Nature: News Feature]</ref> Such education and social trends are increasingly viewed with alarm by the Iranian conservatives groups.<ref name=BBCed/><ref name=VOE>[http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1079460.html Iran: Does Government Fear Educated Women?], Iraj Gorgin, [[Radio Free Europe]], February 10, 2008. Retrieved September 21, 2008.</ref> A report by the Research Center of the [[Majlis]] (controlled by conservatives) warned that the large female enrollment could cause "social disparity and economic and cultural imbalances between men and women."<ref name=BBCed/>
In 1994, [[Ali Khamenei]], [[Supreme leader of Iran]], declared percentage of female university was 33% before [[Islamic Revolution]] but after that on 2012, became 60%.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.khamenei.ir/news/3345/The-educational-status-of-Iranian-women-before-and-after-the | title=The educational status of Iranian women before and after the Revolution | publisher=english.khamenei.ir | date=11 February 2016 | accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref>
The [[Iranian Revolution]] initiated social changes that helped more women enroll in universities. Today more than 60% of all university students in Iran are women.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/5359672.stm BBC NEWS | Middle East | Women graduates challenge Iran<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.parstimes.com/women/women_universities.html Iran: Number Of Female University Students Rising Dramatically<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

Many Iranian women have been influential in the sciences, such as [[Jaleh Amouzgar]], [[Eliz Sanasarian]], [[Janet Afary]], and [[Alenush Terian]]. [[Maryam Mirzakhani]] won gold medals in the 1994 and 1995 International Mathematical Olympiads,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://imo.math.ca/IMO95/newresults.html |title=1995 International Mathematical Olympiad (Unofficial) Results |access-date=September 22, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081002161930/http://imo.math.ca/IMO95/newresults.html |archive-date=October 2, 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and in 2014 her work on dynamics made her the first woman in the world to win the [[Fields medal]], which is widely considered to be the most prestigious award in mathematics.<ref>Ball, Philip. Retrieved 13 August 2014.</ref>
In 2001, [[Allameh Tabatabaii University]], [[Tarbiat Modares University]], and Azzahra University initiated a [[Women's Studies]] academic field at the [[Master of Arts]] level, and shortly thereafter [[Tehran University]] organized a similar program.
== Economic rights ==
During the Achaemenid Empire, women's contribution to the economy was through their engagement in agricultural duties, such as sowing seeds, harvesting, and tending livestock, but their primary role in society was bearing children. In rural areas and amongst poor urban families, women contributed to the economy by specializing in trades, such as making clothing and carpets.<ref name=":26"/>
The rate of women's participation and contribution to Iran's economy "has been 14.7 and 14.4 in urban and rural areas respectively. According to the statistics of the 2006 census, out of the total households having a woman head of 10-year-old and over, only 14.1% in the urban and 13.9 percent in the rural areas have been employed from an economic point of view".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Avazalipour, Zandi, Damankeshideh, Hakimipoor, Faramarzi|first=Mohammad Sadegh, Fatemeh, Marjan, Nader, Ayoub|date=2012|title=The role of women in economic participation and employment: A logistic model for iran|url=|journal=International Journal of Contemporary Mathematical Sciences|volume=6|pages=545–556|via=}}</ref>
Iran's 2007 census showed that 10% of women were actively contributing to the economy. In contrast, over 60% of men were economically active. Statistics show that of the managerial positions available, the possibility of women obtaining such a position is one-third that of men.<ref name=":72"/><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rezazadeh|first=Razieh|date=2011|title=Women Empowerment and Good Urban Governance in Iran|url=|journal=Asian Social Science|volume=7|pages=260–268|via=}}</ref>
As of 2006, women's labor-force participation rates remained very low at 12.6% in rural areas with an overall rate of 12.5%. In contrast, the rate for men is 66.1%. This data is not truly reflective of reality as women's engagement in informal and private sectors are not included in the data.<ref name=":112">{{Cite journal|last=Tohidi|first=Nayereh|date=October 2016|title=Women's Rights and Feminist Movement in Iran|url=|journal=Internatinoal Journal on Human Rights|volume=|pages=75–89|via=}}</ref> [[World Bank]] figure estimates women's participation in all sectors at 32% and 75% for men.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/DATASTATISTICS/0,,content|title=World Bank Online Database|last=|first=|date=2008|website=worldbank.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=17 April 2018}}</ref> The estimated data for women's leadership role is at 3.4% in 2006.<ref name=":112"/>
== Political rights ==
For a short period during the Achaemenian Empire, women rose to power due to a lack of an adult male heir. First [[Boran|Purandukht]] and later [[Azarmidokht|Azarmidukht]] were given the title king of kings and ruled the country for a year. Their reign was short-lived as the Zoroastrian priesthood was against female leadership.<ref name=":26"/>
For most of the Islamic era in Iran, women were not allowed to engage in state affairs. However, soon after the rise of the [[Safavid dynasty]] in the 16th century, women were allowed to contribute to state affairs. Women's position was still subordinate to men, but they were allowed to manage their personal property and participate in cultural activities.<ref name=":26" />
Women gained a foothold in state affairs in the latter part of Pahlavi dynasty as they were given the right to vote. Iran's Queen [[Farah Pahlavi|Farrah Pahlavi]] was at the forefront of the women's movement and worked closely with the Shah to help women gain more rights in the 1960s and 1970s. It was during this period that the first woman was elected to Iran's parliament, Dr. [[Farrokhroo Parsa|Farrakhroo Parsay]], in 1963.<ref name=":26" />
During the first decade after the revolution in the early 1990s, there were only three women in parliament among the 268 members with women occupying 1.5% of the seats in the first three parliaments.<ref name=":122">{{Cite journal|last=Moinifar|first=Heshmat Sadat|date=2009|title=Participation of Women in Iran's Polity|url=|journal=GEMC Journal|volume=|pages=24|via=}}</ref> Today, there are 17 women among the 271 individuals in parliament.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.radiozamaneh.com/280033|title=دهمین دوره مجلس ایران آغاز به‌کار کرد {{!}} رادیو زمانه|date=2016-05-28|work=رادیو زمانه|access-date=2018-05-01}}</ref>
Therefore, women's presence doubled to 3.3% of the seats. The women in parliament have ratified a total of 35 bills concerning women's issues.<ref name=":122" />
== Sports == {{See also|Women's football in Iran}} [[File:Eople watching IRNPOR match at 2018 WC in Tehran's Azadi Stadium 10.jpg|thumb|Women were allowed to enter football stadiums after 40 years to watch the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|FIFA World Cup]] in 2018]] Women contributed to the development of [[polo]] in [[Persia]] 2,500 years ago. "The queen and her ladies-in-waiting played against the emperor and his courtiers."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4272210.stm '' Polo comes back home to Iran'']</ref>
Women participate in numerous sports in Iran and have represented the country in sporting events, such as the [[Asian Games]], [[Olympic Games|Olympic games]], and World Cups. An issue that has been voiced particularly in recent years has been in regard to women's participation at stadiums for men's volleyball and soccer. Efforts have been made to allow women to enter Iranian stadiums alongside men, but the proposal has not yet been approved. The ban on women entering stadiums has caused an uproar among both men and women in Iran. It has been indicated numerous times by lawmakers that women's duty is to raise children and not to attend sporting games.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/19/sports/olympics/women-denied-entry-to-volleyball-event-thats-the-real-crime.html|title=Women Denied Entry to Volleyball Event: That’s the Real Crime|last=Macur|first=Juliet|date=2016-02-18|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-01|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> On 9 November 2018 [[Fatma Samoura]] Secretary General of International Federation of Football Association FIFA said she would ask Iranian government to end ban on women’s entry to sport stadiums.<ref>[https://en.radiofarda.com/a/fifa-engage-iran-on-women-allowed-in-stadiums/29590427.html FIFA To Engage With Iran To Lift Ban On Women In Stadiums]</ref>
Women are not allowed to ride bicycles in Iran pursuant to an Islamic fatwa issued by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's Supreme Leader and autocrat. According to the Muslim clerics of Iran, if a man observes a woman riding a bicycle, it will lead to corruption in society with terrible consequences, including corruption that will lead to crime, sexual offenses, financial crimes, spiritual infidelity, religious disobedience, and many others.[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-42|<sup>[42]]]
==Women's health== {{See also|Health care in Iran|Family planning in Iran}} The average life expectancy for Iranian women has increased from 44.2 years in 1960 to an average of 75.7 years in 2012 and the maternal mortality rate dropped from 83 to 23 per 100,000 between 1990 and 2013. In the 20th century, female social activists, health workers, and non-governmental organizations promoted the health of women by stressing the importance of regular check-ups such as the [[Pap smear]], [[mammography]], and blood tests. Vitamin D and calcium supplementation and [[Hormone replacement therapy (menopause)|hormone replacement therapy]] were emphasized with the goal of preventing [[osteoporosis]]. Even with the increased life expectancy that Iranian females have gained within the last 50 years, HIV/AIDS has become an alarming health problem among Iranian females. The [[HIV]]/AIDS rate with Iranian females has increased over five times between 2007 and 2015. As for concerns with mental health, depression in Iranian women was ranked first among diseases in 2011 compared to their second-place ranking in 2003. As for their social health, the delinquency of women has increased in recent years with crimes related to drugs and violence compared to Iranian men.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Joulaei|first=Hassan|last2=Maharlouei|first2=Najmeh|last3=lankarani|first3=Kamran Bagheri|last4=Razzaghi|first4=Alireza|last5=Akbari|first5=Maryam|date=2016-01-01|title=Narrative review of women’s health in Iran: challenges and successes|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1186/s12939-016-0316-x|journal=International Journal for Equity in Health|volume=15|pages=25|doi=10.1186/s12939-016-0316-x|issn=1475-9276|pmc=4754925|pmid=26880036}}</ref>
In 2005, the Iranian parliament approved abortions carried out before four months gestation if a woman's life was at risk or if the fetus was malformed. With technical support from the [[United Nations Population Fund]], the government undertook literacy and family planning initiatives. The fund's specific contributions to the Literacy Movement Organization of Iran included training more than 7,000 teachers, developing a nine-episode television series on women's health issues (including family planning), and procuring computers and other equipment.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.americansforunfpa.org/site/c.enKMIRNpEkG/b.1568015/k.C97A/Adult_Education_Offers_Options_to_Iranian_Women.htm |title=''Adult Education Offers Options to Iranian Women'' |access-date=August 12, 2006 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070221082253/http://www.americansforunfpa.org/site/c.enKMIRNpEkG/b.1568015/k.C97A/Adult_Education_Offers_Options_to_Iranian_Women.htm |archive-date=February 21, 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Women's rights movement in Iran== [[File:Jam'iat e nesvan e vatan-khah01.jpg|thumb|The board of directors of "[[Jam'iat e nesvan e vatan-khah]]", a women's rights association in Tehran (1923-1933)]] {{main|Women's rights movement in Iran}} {{see also|Women's fraction|Vice Presidency for Women and Family Affairs|List of female members of the Cabinet of Iran|List of female members of the Islamic Consultative Assembly}}
Women's efforts to seek equal rights date back to the 19th and early 20th centuries. There is little available information on women's rights movements prior to the Qajar dynasty, but more accounts are available from the Qajar and post Qajar era. Women's movements in Iran can be divided into eight periods.<ref name=":112"/>
1905-1925: this period was during the constitutional revolution, which marked the end of the Qajar dynasty. Women's efforts were mostly secretive, and their goals were to improve literacy, women's health, and prevent polygamy and domestic violence.<ref name=":112" />
1925-1940's: This era is marked by the beginning of the Pahlavi dynasty and the reign of Reza Shah. It was a new era in which women were unveiled and gained access to universities.<ref name=":112" />
1940's-1950's: The era of nationalization of [[Iran's oil industry]] brought women further access to education and political activism to some extent. However, aside from the Family Protection Law that failed and was repealed, no major reforms were made during this era.<ref name=":112" />
1960's-1970's: During the era of the White Revolution and period of modernization, women saw greater legal reforms concerning voting rights, family protection laws, as well as an increase in women's participation in the economy.<ref name=":112" />
1979-1997: The era of the revolution featuring change to the political sphere, caused the closure of women's centers and the decline of women's contributions to the economy.<ref name=":112" />
1997-2005: Khatami's era and the era of reforms gave more access to the feminist press and free press.<ref name=":112" />
2005-2013: The [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad|Ahmadinejad]] era or the neo-conservative era saw the increase of repression and the rise of unemployment.<ref name=":112" />
2013–Present: The era of moderation under the rule of President Rouhani has not seen any major reforms related to the status of women as hardliners already repealed most reforms.<ref name=":112" />
In the mid 19th century, [[Táhirih|Tahirih]] was the first woman to appear in public without wearing a veil, and she is known as the mother of the women's rights movements in Iran. After Tahirih, there were others who followed in her footsteps to raise the status of women.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zahedi|first=Ashraf|date=2007-08-27|title=Contested Meaning of the Veil and Political Ideologies of Iranian Regimes|url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/219931|journal=Journal of Middle East Women's Studies|volume=3|issue=3|pages=75–98|issn=1558-9579}}</ref> Among these individuals was Safiya Yazdi, the wife of a leading clergy, [[Muhammad Husain Yazdi]]. [[Safiya Yazdi]], with the support of her husband, opened [[Iffatiyah Girls School]] in 1910 and gained praise for her outspoken lectures on women's issues .<ref name=":42"/>
Women in Iran are becoming increasingly informed about the current trends within global feminism. They are also becoming more transnationally engaged, especially with regard to the mechanisms, tools, and machineries created through the U.N. gender projects and conventions, such as [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women|CEDAW]]. However, due to the vetting power of the conservative Guardian Council, attempts made by the reformist deputies in the [[sixth Majlis]] to ratify CEDAW did not succeed. Most women activists, including Islamic as well as secular ones, have been framing their demands within the [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women|CEDAW]] framework.<ref name=":112" />
In recent years, the government has made investments in women's organizations and women's activist initiatives that seek to empower women to learn skills that can help women gain more independence.<ref name=":010"/>
The women's rights movement in Iran continues to attempt to institute reforms, particularly with the [[One Million Signatures]] Campaign to End Discrimination Against Women.[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-Democracy Digest-58|<sup>[58]</sup>]]

Retrieved September 21, 2008.</ref> The feat, undertaken in [[Kazakhstan]], was reportedly an inspiration to many Iranian women.<ref name=Space/>
=== Relationship with western feminism === Some suggest that only by accepting help from western feminists, whose progress has been recognized within western society, can the Iranian Women's Movement be recognized. This perspective suggests that western feminism can offer freedom and opportunity to Iranian women that their own religious society cannot. In addition, advocates of this view argue that no matter what the Iranian Women's Movement is able to achieve within Iranian society, the status of individual women within this society will always be less than what has been achieved by western feminists.<ref name="Darraj, Susan Muaddi 2002">Darraj, Susan Muaddi. “Understanding the Other Sister: The Case of Arab Feminism.” Monthly Review: An Independent Socialist Magazine 53.10 (2002): 15–26.</ref>
By contrast, others suggest that parochial movements of women will never be successful, and that until a global sisterhood made up of women from all nations and religions has been established, feminism has not truly arrived.<ref>Fathi, Asghar. “Communities in Place and Communities in Space: Globalization and Feminism in Iran.” Women, Religion and Culture in Iran. Ed. Sarah Ansari and Vanessa Martin. Surrey, UK: Curzon, 2002. 215–224. </ref>
There is a third perspective suggesting that a global women's movement will inevitably ignore and undermine the unique elements of indigenous Iranian feminism which have arisen as a result of their history and religion.<ref name="Darraj, Susan Muaddi 2002"/>
Signing the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights a multilateral treaty adopted by the United Nations has not improved women's situation much either. Howland in her book “Religious Fundamentalism and the Human Rights of Women” concerning the individual liberty within a democracy makes two suggestions to “the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights ([[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights|ICCPR]]), [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights|"a major human right treaty with 140 states]]"... Her first suggestion is "that in a spirit of democracy we first have to recognize that many of the women’s rights at stake in this context are core civil and political rights rather than simply issues of gender equality within the family.”<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Religious Fundamentalisms and the human rights for women|last=Howland|first=Courtney|publisher=Springer|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=93–105}}</ref> She further explains ”that religious fundamentalist has structured the dialogue to make the dispute appear to be about women’s rights within the family or private issues of religious belief,<ref name=":1" />” but she argues that “there has been little focus on recognizing these so-called private rights and wrongs within the family as public political rights"<ref name=":1" />... The second suggestion made by Howland is that “a state should be obligated to protest its citizens against certain actions that have heretofore been characterized as private.”<ref name=":1" />
==Crimes against women== [[Amnesty International]] noted in 2008 that the extent and prevalence of violence against women in the Kurdish regions of Iran is impossible to quantify, but discrimination and violence against women and girls in the Kurdish regions is both pervasive and widely tolerated. Furthermore, Kurdish cultural norms which facilitate the practice of forced child marriage perpetuate the fear of violence amongst Kurdish girls in Iran.[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-Amnesty International 2008-68|<sup href="sanshou">[68]</sup>]] In 2008, self-immolation "occurred in all the areas of Kurdish settlement (in Iran), where it was more common than in other parts of Iran".[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-amnesty.org-69|<sup href="canoe polo">[69]</sup>]] It was reported that in 2001, 565 women lost their lives in honor-related crimes in [[Ilam, Iran]], of which 375 were reportedly staged as self-immolation.[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-amnesty.org-69|<sup href="Warsaw">[69]</sup>]]
In Iran, [[Honor killing|honour killings]] occur primarily among tribal minority groups, such as the [[Kurds|Kurdish]], [[Arabic|Arab]], [[Lori people|Lori]], [[Baloch people|Baluchi]], and [[Turkish-speaking tribes]], while honor-related crimes are not a tradition among Persians who are generally less socially conservative. Discriminatory [[family law]]s, articles in the [[Criminal code|Criminal Code]] that show leniency towards honor killings, and a strongly male dominated society have been cited as causes of honor killings in Iran.[[Women's rights in Iran#cite note-74|<sup>[74]</sup>]]

{{short description|term for people born during Generation X/Millennial cusp years}} '''''Xennials''''' (also known as the '''Oregon Trail Generation''' and '''Generation Catalano''') is a [[neologistic]] term used to describe people born during the [[Generation X]]/[[Millennials|Millennial]] [[Cuspers|cusp]] years, typically from the late 1970s to the early 1980s. People who identify with Xennials, Oregon Trail Generation or Generation Catalano do so because they do not feel they fit within the typical definitions of Generation X or Millennials.
In 2017, ''Xennial'' was included in [[Merriam-Webster]]'s "Words We're Watching" section which discusses new words which are increasingly being used, but which do not yet meet criteria for a dictionary entry.
==Terminology== The term "Xennials" is a [[portmanteau]] blending the names of [[Generation X]] and the [[Millennials]] to describe individuals born during the Generation X/Millennial cusp years of the late 1970s to the early 1980s.<ref name=Stankorb>{{cite web | url = http://magazine.good.is/articles/generation-xennials | title = Reasonable People Disagree about the Post-Gen X, Pre-Millennial Generation | last1 = Stankorb | last2 = Oelbaum | first1 = Sarah | first2 = Jed | date = 25 September 2014 | website = Good Magazine | publisher = [[Good Worldwide]]| access-date = 6 November 2015 | quote = }}</ref>
The term Xennial is reported to be first created and used in a September 2014 article in [[Good Worldwide|GOOD magazine]] <ref name=Stankorb/> written by Sarah Stankorb and Jed Oelbaum.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/what-is-a-xennial-definition-attribution|title=I Made Up Xennial 3 Years Ago, So Why Is a Professor in Australia Getting All the Credit?|work=Vogue|access-date=2017-11-10|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171114140642/https://www.vogue.com/article/what-is-a-xennial-definition-attribution#|archive-date=2017-11-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Good magazine describes Xennials as "a micro-generation that serves as a bridge between the disaffection of Gen X and the blithe optimism of Millennials", using it to describe those born between 1977 and 1983.<ref name=Guardian>{{cite news|title=Are you a xennial? Take the quiz|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2017/jun/27/are-you-a-xennial-take-the-quiz|accessdate=1 July 2017|publisher=The Guardian|date=26 June 2017}}</ref> The term Xennials received additional attention in June 2017 following an [[Instagram]] post<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.instagram.com/p/BUcbF-0D41H/ | title = What is a Xennial? | last = Davies | first = P.H. | date = 23 May 2017 | website= Instagram | publisher = Instagram | access-date = 23 May 2017 |quote=}}</ref> describing it which went [[Viral phenomenon|viral]] on [[Facebook]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Vitto|first1=Laura|title=Hey 30-somethings, you're a Xennial|url=http://mashable.com/2017/06/30/xennials-versus-other-generations/#S0x4LbkbBaqj|accessdate=5 July 2017|publisher=Mashable|date=30 June 2017}}</ref> Dan Woodman, an Australian sociologist, was credited by the Australian media with inventing the term, but Woodman says he did not coin the term.<ref name=Guardian/>, and the earliest traced usage is the 2014 article from Good magazine.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/what-is-a-xennial-definition-attribution|title=I Made Up Xennial 3 Years Ago, So Why Is a Professor in Australia Getting All the Credit?|work=Vogue|access-date=2017-11-10|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171114140642/https://www.vogue.com/article/what-is-a-xennial-definition-attribution#|archive-date=2017-11-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In 2018, Marleen Stollen writing for ''[[Business Insider]]'' described Xennials as term for people who don't feel like a Gen Xer or a Millennial. She used birth dates between 1977 and 1985 in her article to describe them.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/people-born-between-gen-x-millennials-xennials-2017-11|title=There's a term for people born in the early 80's who don't feel like a millennial or Gen Xer|last1=Stollen|first1=Marleen|date=10 January 2018|accessdate=2 May 2018|publisher=Business Insider}}</ref>
The term ''Oregon Trail Generation'' was used by Anna Garvey in her 2015 article "The Oregon Trail Generation: Life Before And After Mainstream Tech", published in ''Social Media Week'' to describe those born at "the tail end of the 70s and the start of the 80s".<ref name=Garvey>{{cite web | url = http://socialmediaweek.org/blog/2015/04/oregon-trail-generation/ | title = The Oregon Trail Generation: Life Before And After Mainstream Tech | last = Garvey | first = Anna | date = 21 April 2015 | website = Social Media Week | publisher = Crowdcentric Media, LLC. | access-date = 6 November 2015 | quote = }}</ref> It is named after the video game ''[[The Oregon Trail (1985 video game)|The Oregon Trail]]'', the [[Apple II]] version of which was played by many American GenX/Millennial [[cusper]]s in their school computer labs.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wagner|first1=Tony|title=What did Oregon Trail teach us?|url=https://www.marketplace.org/2017/05/05/tech/make-me-smart-kai-and-molly/blog-what-did-oregon-trail-teach-us|accessdate=14 May 2017|publisher=Marketplace|date=8 May 2017}}</ref> Other terms, such as Xennials, Generation Catalano<ref name=Shafrir>{{cite web | url = http://www.slate.com/articles/life/culturebox/2011/10/generation_catalano_the_generation_stuck_between_gen_x_and_the_m.single.html | title = Generation Catalano | last = Shafrir | first = Doree | date = 24 October 2011 | website = Slate | publisher = The Slate Group | access-date = 6 November 2015 | quote = }}</ref> and The Lucky Ones<ref>{{cite news|last1=Anna|first1=Garvey|title=The Biggest Difference Between Millennials and My Generation|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/anna-garvey/the-biggest-and-best-difference-between-millennials_b_7438370.html|accessdate=25 February 2017|publisher=Huffington Post|date=25 May 2016}}</ref> were already coined and are referenced in her article.<ref name=Garvey/>
''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' defines Generation Catalano as being born from 1977 to 1981, essentially [[Jimmy Carter]]'s presidency. The name is a reference to the character Jordan Catalano from the 1990s teen drama ''[[My So-Called Life]]''.<ref name=Shafrir/>
[[Merriam-Webster]] includes ''Xennial'' in their Words We're Watching section, defining the term as "a word that refers to people who were born on the cusp between Generation X and the millennials. Some consider 'xennials' to be those born between 1977 and 1983."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/words-at-play/words-were-watching-xennial|title=Words We're Watching: 'Xennial'|access-date=2017-12-02|language=en}}</ref>
==Characteristics and traits== Many who identify with the cusp years of Oregon Trail Generation, Xennials or Generation Catalano do so because they do not feel they fit within the typical definitions of [[Generation X]] or [[Millennials]].<ref name=Shafrir /><ref name=LaFrance>{{cite web | url = https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2016/02/how-generations-get-their-names/459720/ | title = How Generations Get Their Names | last = LaFrance| first = Adrienne| date = 3 February 2016 | website= The Atlantic | publisher = Atlantic Media Company | access-date = 22 June 2016 |quote=}}</ref><ref name=Kendzior>{{cite web | url = http://qz.com/720456/the-myth-of-millennial-entitlement-was-created-to-hide-their-parents-mistakes/ | title = The myth of millennial entitlement was created to hide their parents' mistakes | last = Kendzior | first = Sarah | date = 30 June 2016 | website= Quartz | publisher = Atlantic Media Company | access-date = 7 July 2016 |quote=}}</ref> Cassie McClure, writing for ''[[Las Cruces Sun-News]],'' describes those in the Oregon Trail Generation as "remembering a time before the digital age, but barely".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.lcsun-news.com/story/life/sunlife/2016/05/20/my-so-called-millennial-life-old-west-pioneers-digital-age/84227566/ | title = My So-Called Millennial Life: Old West pioneers of digital age | last = McClure | first = Cassie | date = 20 May 2016 | website= Las Cruces Sun-News | publisher = The USA Today Network | access-date = 22 June 2016 |quote=}}</ref> Anna Garvey describes these individuals as having "both a healthy portion of Gen X grunge cynicism, and a dash of the unbridled optimism of Millennials", and discusses their relationship with both analog and digital technology.<ref name=Garvey/> Sheknows.com describes individuals born in the late 1970s and early 1980s as sharing traits with both Generation X and Millennials.<ref name=Fogarty>{{cite web | url = http://www.sheknows.com/living/articles/1105987/stuck-between-gen-x-millennials | title = 13 Signs you're stuck between Gen X & millennials | last = Fogarty | first = Lisa | date = 7 January 2016 | website= SheKnows| publisher = SheKnows Media | access-date = 22 June 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
Anna Garvey describes U.S members of this group as having had an "[[AOL]] adolescence" and as being from "the last gasp of a time before [[sexting]], [[Facebook]] shaming, and constant communication".<ref name=Garvey/> ''[[The Dickinson Press]]'' describes those born in the early 1980s as having early adulthoods which were impacted by the events of the [[September 11 attacks]] and the [[Iraq War]].<ref name=Monke>{{cite web | url = http://www.thedickinsonpress.com/opinion/columns/3756532-monke-generation-stuck-transition | title = Monke: A generation stuck in transition | last = Monke| first = Dustin| date = 31 May 2015 | website= The Dickinson Press | publisher = The Dickinson Press and Forum Communications Company | access-date = 22 June 2016 |quote=}}</ref>
According to Australian sociologist, Dan Woodman, "The theory goes that the Xennials dated, and often formed ongoing relationships, pre-social media. They usually weren't on [[Tinder (app)|Tinder]] or [[Grindr]], for their first go at dating at least. They called up their friends and the person they wanted to ask out on a [[landline|landline phone]], hoping that it wasn't their intended date's parent who picked up.." Woodman also says "the 'Xennials' must be taken with several grains of salt. There isn't yet any strong academic evidence for the grouping, although clearly the idea resonates with a lot of people who felt left out by the usual categorizations."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Woodman |first1=Dan |title=From Boomers to Xennials: we love talking about our generations, but must recognise their limits |url=https://theconversation.com/from-boomers-to-xennials-we-love-talking-about-our-generations-but-must-recognise-their-limits-80679 |accessdate=13 June 2018 |publisher=The Conversation |date=12 July 2017}}</ref>
